characters: I DEMAND THAT WE RELIEVE COLONEL
ARMED FORCES, HITLER'S SECOND IN COMMAND.
MAMA, COME DOWN. PAPA IS HERE. PAPA
THE MILITARY DISTRICT. FORCED OUT BY HITLER, 1938.
OPERATION VAL- WHO GAVE THE ORDER
THIS IS NOTHING LESS THAN TREASON.
OFFER IT TO THEM BEFORE THEY ARE IN
THIS IS ABOUT GERMANY, FOR GOD'S
DON'T ARGUE WITH ME, DAMMIT. JUST
SAKE. NOT YOU. BE A MAN.

dialogues.speaker: MARCH 1943.
dialogues.text: A lonely airfield. A NAZI OFFICER and his AIDE stand rigid by a gleaming limousine. The officer's uniform denotes a man of high rank - a man of weight.

dialogues.speaker: STAFF FOR ARMY GROUP CENTER.
dialogues.text: Tresckow smokes a cigarette, his arm the only movement in the frame. PULL BACK TO REVEAL the airstrip is surrounded by Army Group vehicles and personnel - SD and SS escorts, photographers, aides, Nazi party dignitaries, etc. - all frozen like statues. Eerie. Whatever is going on, it's big. The faint sound of distant airplanes brings tension, subtle but sharp. Approaching the field are three Focke-Wulf 200 Condors escorted by a formation of Messerschmitt-109 fighters. Silence gives way to an escalating roar that seems to have no maximum. One by one, the massive four-engine Condors land while the fighters roar overhead and circle the airfield. The Condors come to rest and, needing no introduction: ADOLF HITLER alights from the lead plane, obscured by the surrounding platoon of heavily armed SS GUARDS. (Note: Hitler is obscured throughout the entire sequence proving how inaccessible he truly was.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tresckow and his Aide step forward to greet Hitler, but they are pushed back by SS guards. The FГјhrer marches past without so much a glance at his hosts or their waiting limo. To Tresckow's surprise, a second limousine roars onto the airfield from out of nowhere. It is dirty, the windscreen spotted with bugs from a long drive. Hitler gets in the dirty car and speeds off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not so much your car he doesn't trust... It's your driver. Tresckow and his Aide turn. Standing behind them is:

dialogues.speaker: OF THE ARMY OPERATIONS SECTION.
dialogues.text: The consummate Nazi, he is always scribbling notes in a small datebook. Without looking up, Brandt hops into the limo they brought for Hitler. Tresckow and his Aide share a glance and get in. A beat later they are speeding after Hitler's car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Est. Hitler's headquarters for the Eastern Front is bustling. Security is tight, everyone is on edge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Long tables packed with SOLDIERS straining their necks to get a glimpse of their leader at the head table, but he is obscured by his detail of SS guards. ONE MAN dares to approach. The room falls silent. HITLER'S PERSONAL CHEF places a tray before the FГјhrer, producing a knife and fork, cutting a bite. We think he is going to hand feed Hitler until he places the food in his own mouth, chewing slowly, deliberately. He swallows. We wait for him to die. When he doesn't, Hitler begins to eat. The rest of the room relaxes slightly and digs in. ANGLE ON: Seated further down the table are Tresckow and his Aide. Between them, once again, is Brandt, eating like a pig, still making notes in his book. Tresckow stares.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Managing the FГјhrer's security must be quite an undertaking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in between mouthfuls)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Irregularity is the FГјhrer's                             precaution of choice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can assure you he's safe here. Relax, Brandt. Enjoy your meal. Brandt's look says, "Don't be ridiculous." He cleans his plate in seconds. Then he gently dabs his mouth, takes out his datebook and starts writing - once again the precise man we saw on the airfield. TRESCKOW (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I understand you're returning to Berlin this afternoon... Brandt nods. TRESCKOW (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Could I trouble you to deliver a package to Colonel Stieff? Brandt nods again, too busy writing to notice the knowing glance Tresckow shares with his Aide...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tense silence. Tresckow and his Aide are hunched over two bottles of Cointreau on a large desk next to: TWO PAIRS OF BRITISH `CLAMS' - a small black plastic casing held together by magnets and adhesive tape. Tresckow inserts a short, pencil-shaped fuse through the narrow opening. All that remains exposed is a small glass capsule. The trigger. Tresckow turns his attention to the bottles of Cointreau...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Condors' engines roar, ready for take off. Soldiers stand at attention as Hitler boards. Brandt is with him, scribbling in his ever-present datebook.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tresckow and his Aide approach. Tresckow gently handles a carefully wrapped package. CLOSE ON: Tresckow presses a key against the side of the package, crushing the glass capsule inside. The explosive armed now, he hands it to Brandt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With my regards to Colonel Stieff. Brandt accepts the gift, looking up from his book. He studies the familiar shape.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cointreau? You better hope I don't get thirsty on the flight. Tresckow politely smiles, hiding his nerves, having just handed a bomb to Hitler's Head of Security. Brandt unknowingly carries it onto the plane with Hitler. The door to the Condor is sealed behind him along with, we hope, the FГјhrer's fate. Tresckow looks at his watch and we DISSOLVE TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A clock shows us that thirty minutes have passed. Tresckow and his Aide are seated on either side of a desk staring at the telephone. Smoking. Waiting...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Three hours later. The ashtray is overflowing but Tresckow and his Aide have not moved. Finally... The phone barely rings before Tresckow answers. He doesn't say a word, he only nods and hangs up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's... landed. It takes a moment for the gravity of this to set in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about the... Tresckow is already dialing the telephone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get me Colonel Brandt... (staying cool)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Colonel? Tresckow... I trust you landed safely... I hate to trouble you but there's been a bit of a mix up. It seems you have the wrong bottles for Colonel Stieff. You... do still have the package? Long pause. Torture. Then: TRESCKOW (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can be at your office first thing tomorrow morning to pick it up. Terribly sorry for the inconvenience... Thank you. Tresckow slowly hangs up the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you think he knows? Tresckow shrugs, opening a bottle of Cointreau and pouring two glasses with a shaking hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's only one way to be sure...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Est. An early morning fog blankets the ground, obscuring our view. Eerie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Footsteps echo through the cavernous hallways. Tresckow marches with purpose through the numerous security checkpoints. It is a long, suspenseful walk. He is aware of someone walking up behind him, getting closer. We think he's done for, but a BESPECTACLED, MIDDLE-AGED OFFICER overtakes him and whispers:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happened?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TRESCKOW

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can only guess the altitude                         caused the fuse to malfunction.                       First the beer hall, Memorial Day -                   now this. Someone is watching over                    that sonofabitch, I swear it.                         OLBRICHT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've been discovered.                                Tresckow halts and faces Olbricht, expressionless. TRESCKOW

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What makes you think- OLBRICHT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oster's been arrested. The Gestapo came for him last night. Tresckow thinks for a beat and resumes walking. Olbricht hurries after him.

dialogues.speaker: OLBRICHT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Did you hear what I said? TRESCKOW

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Gestapo could have arrested him for anything. Find a replacement.                     OLBRICHT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's no one we can trust. Not in                   Berlin.                                               TRESCKOW

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then stop looking in Berlin.                          Just then, they approach the final threshold, a SENTRY guards an office marked: COLONEL HEINZ BRANDT. Olbricht stops, regarding the door with dread. But Tresckow presses on, reaching the door, about to enter when: SENTRY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your pistol please. Oh shit. Tresckow plays it cool, removing his pistol from its holster and handing it over. And with a nod to Olbricht, Tresckow squares his shoulders and enters Brandt's office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brandt is at his desk, writing as always. Tresckow notices Brandt's pistol sitting within arm's reach. A clock ticks loudly. Imagine it. Then wait. Finally: Brandt puts his pen down, stands and salutes, but the gesture is almost casual. Pure formality.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll forgive me, General. This                         little round-up has had me writing                       reports all day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Round-up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dissenters. A plot against the                           FГјhrer.                                                  Tresckow makes a good show of laughing that off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who would even have the balls?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'd be surprised, the number of                        cowards in this army that would be                       willing to stand against the Reich.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only if the FГјhrer were dead, of                         course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course. It's one thing to think                       you know what's right. What matters                      is having the strength to do it.                         Clunk. Brandt produces the package, putting it on the desk in front of him. BRANDT (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is this what you've come for?                            Pause. Staying cool, Tresckow reaches for it: BRANDT (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perhaps we should open it. Tresckow freezes, studies Brandt's cold smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I beg your pardon. Brandt sits back, smiles. Does he know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've come a long way. You must be thirsty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wonder how the FГјhrer, who does not partake, would feel about an officer who did so on duty... Colonel Brandt. Brandt's smile fades. We can't decide why. He picks up the package carelessly. Tresckow stays cool despite the armed explosive just a few feet away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I took you for another sort, General. And we realize he really did just want a drink. He knows nothing about what the package hides.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I you. Tresckow reaches out, grabbing the package and: BANG. The sound of an EXPLOSION O.S. takes us to:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Moving rapidly through an olive grove in the otherwise wasted desert. A column of tanks, trucks and heavy equipment flow by with a sense of barely contained chaos. Men dismantle tents from around others dumping documents into burning oil drums. In the middle of it we find a tall, handsome young officer (age 35). He wears an Afrika Korps uniform complete with Colonel's badges, staying cooler than the other side of your pillow. He directs men this way and that, holding back panic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A jeep speeds up to him from the distance, driven by a YOUNG LIEUTENANT.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG LIEUTENANT
dialogues.text: Colonel Stauffenberg, sir. A new headquarters has been established at Mezzouna. I'm to take you there. Stauffenberg looks over the scene, expressionless. STAUFFENBERG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now they tell us to disengage - a day late. No matter how many times we tell Command the reality, they always manage to leave us- But he stops himself, containing his rage.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG LIEUTENANT
dialogues.text: Colonel, the enemy is less than five kilometers from here. You've done all you can. Stauffenberg glances at his right hand, contemplating a ring on his finger. After a beat: STAUFFENBERG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wonder... Was there even a point in our coming to Tunis?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG LIEUTENANT
dialogues.text: To get taken prisoner, it seems. Stauffenberg smiles bitterly and gets in the jeep as: BOOM. The first bomb explodes before we even see the tight formation of BRITISH FIRE-BOMBERS overhead. Fighter planes strafe with machine-guns. Artillery blasts strike in front and behind the retreating column. The 10th Panzer Division is trapped. Panic hits the column like a tidal wave. Stauffenberg taps the Young Lieutenant who drives into the melee. Soldiers abandon their vehicles but cover is in short supply and many are left in the open. So they run. Dozens are gunned down by the assailing fighters. The survivors watch in horror as the fighters slowly turn to make another run. In a panic, the soldiers run the other direction, halted by a jeep blocking the way. Stauffenberg stands in the passenger seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: STAUFFENBERG

dialogues.speaker: STOP. WAIT UNTIL THEY COMMIT.
dialogues.text: The men calm when they see the Colonel, trusting him. They turn and watch the formation of planes complete their turn and bear down, gaining speed. Knees tense, some jerking from the natural inclination to flee. STAUFFENBERG (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: STAND FAST, I SAID.
dialogues.text: They do, despite the menace of the planes' engines growing louder, meaner...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The confused PILOT takes in the mass of motionless men below. His finger tenses on the trigger and...

dialogues.speaker: NOW.
dialogues.text: The mob of soldiers breaks - some right, some left - as the fighters open fire on what had been the center of their mass. Unable to change course quickly enough, they spray their lead into the sand. In that same instant, Stauffenberg drops into his seat, the Young Lieutenant jams the jeep in drive and a wave of hot lead misses them by mere feet. Stauffenberg watches his men regroup, waiting out the turning squadron. They've got the idea now. He turns to his Lieutenant who smiles admiringly. But Stauffenberg's eyes widen. He grabs his Lieutenant's head and jams it down, revealing a STRAY FIGHTER coming up from behind. Stauffenberg ducks out of frame, shielding the Young Lieutenant with his body. BANG. Blood sprays across the jeep's windshield before bullets rip it to pieces, leaving only clear blue African sky... And then the EXPLOSION. SILENCE. FADE TO WHITE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A fast clicking. Heels on linoleum. A beautiful, dignified woman keeps herself from running. She is: NINA VON STAUFFENBERG (30), Stauffenberg's wife and mother of his four children. Beside her is BERTHOLD VON STAUFFENBERG (38), Stauffenberg's older brother. They reach the door of a private hospital room just as A DOCTOR comes out. Awkward pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Stauffenberg?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nodding, gesturing to Berthold) The Colonel's brother, Berthold.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perhaps before you see the Colonel we should go to my office and-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will see my husband now. The Doctor wants to argue but Nina's eyes shut him down. He opens the door and they enter to find:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A mass of mummy-like bandages with only small openings around the mouth and one eye. The arms and hands are also wrapped in heavy dressing. No movement but for the rise and fall of the patient's chest. Berthold cannot look. Holding back her anguish, Nina bravely turns to the Doctor. "Well?"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's been constant with fever but he refuses any pain killers. The right hand has been amputated above the wrist. He's lost the fourth and fifth fingers on the left. We... couldn't save the left eye. Berthold covers his face. Nina is a rock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His ring.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He had a ring on his right hand. Where is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry... His hand was amputated in the field... I'm afraid-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.                                                As in: "That will be all." The Doctor leaves. Nina sits beside her husband. She shows him a photo of FOUR BEAUTIFUL CHILDREN - three boys and a girl. Stauffenberg tries to speak but can't. His eye begins to tear. Nina removes a ring from her finger, placing it on a chain with a cross she takes from around her neck. It is identical to the ring Stauffenberg wore in Africa. CLOSE ON: The engraving inside the band - finis- initium [end-beginning]. Nina places the ring and chain on her husband's chest, her hand lingering. She cannot hold the tears back any longer. She stands and turns away, not wanting her husband to see. Berthold takes her place. Stauffenberg struggles to speak. Berthold puts an ear to the hole where Stauffenberg's mouth is - making out his question, even if we can't. Berthold debates answering, then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've lost North Africa. CLOSE ON: That one eye staring at us closes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stauffenberg's bandages are gone - a black patch covering what had been his left eye. The chain with the cross and ring from Nina hangs around his neck. ANOTHER PATIENT lies motionless in the next bed. A man's belongings tell you more about him than he ever could. Stauffenberg's side of the room is neatly arranged, books of poetry and philosophy are well worn. Beside them are his own writings - the print meticulous and flowing. Up to a certain date. After that a new, child-like hand has taken over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A family photograph shows the Stauffenberg's of another generation - wealthy aristocrats from a bygone era. He is a teenager in this photo and smiling broadly. A smile he left in Africa. Stauffenberg's three fingers push a cotton ball under his eyepatch to dab the empty socket. Then he goes to button his shirt. Holding his collar in his teeth, he tries to do the buttons with the use of only three fingers on his left hand. It is heartbreaking to watch. He is about to give up when he notices a figure looming in the doorway. General Olbricht. He winces at the sight of Stauffenberg's deformities. STAUFFENBERG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know what I ever did with ten. Olbricht manages a smile, he moves to speak, but Stauffenberg beats him to it.

dialogues.speaker: STAUFFENBERG, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'm wanted in Berlin. Olbricht nods.

dialogues.speaker: STAUFFENBERG, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Are you asking as a member of the High Command? Olbricht contemplates his answer. He carefully closes the door behind him, nervously glancing at the patient in the next bed.

dialogues.speaker: STAUFFENBERG, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You can speak openly, General. He died just before you came in. Awkward moment. Finally: OLBRICHT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We could use your help. STAUFFENBERG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm a field officer. Olbricht steps closer, speaking openly now. OLBRICHT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This war can't be won in the field.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: STAUFFENBERG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's unfortunate for me.                          OLBRICHT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't honestly believe you'll make a difference on the front- STAUFFENBERG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm a soldier, General. I serve my country. OLBRICHT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It makes no sense. You opposed Hitler, you opposed the war. STAUFFENBERG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The people chose otherwise and here we are. Now we have to win. You know what will happen if we don't. OLBRICHT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If we win, it will still be Hitler's Germany. STAUFFENBERG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We all took an oath, General.                       Olbricht nods, resigning. He realizes it is no use. Finally, he produces a blue velvet box, opening it to reveal a brilliant gold medal. OLBRICHT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On behalf of the FГјhrer. Stauffenberg takes the medal and studies it. STAUFFENBERG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm a twin, you know. Olbricht is as confused as we are. OLBRICHT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I... I didn't. STAUFFENBERG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My brother died the day after we were born. OLBRICHT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. What the hell is he talking about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was lying in the desert, covered in blood, sure I was going to die. I tried to think about my wife, my children... But my mind kept drifting to my dead brother. How I would finally be with him. How I would finally be whole again... He snaps out of his thoughts, holding up his arm. STAUFFENBERG (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is my reward for what happened to my men. It's all I deserve. Stauffenberg nonchalantly tosses the medal into a nearby bedpan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON: A field of white. A three fingered hand enters the frame, gently placing a medal identical to the one just saw. PULL BACK TO REVEAL: Stauffenberg, done up in his finest dress uniform, placing said medal on an unconscious WOUNDED SOLDIER. AN AIDE stands behind him, carrying a silver tray stacked with MANY BOXES containing such medals. PULL BACK FURTHER TO REVEAL: Stauffenberg stands between two long rows of beds, each with A WOUNDED SOLDIER. Those that can respond to Stauffenberg do so with reverence. The ward is eerily silent. With only three fingers, Stauffenberg cannot pin the medals to his men. He has to settle for simply laying them on a each soldier's chest or a pillow. With each medal he presents, the task becomes harder to watch. Suddenly, Stauffenberg freezes, finding himself looking at THE YOUNG LIEUTENANT - his driver in Africa. The young man is a mass of bandages, his legs gone, his face smashed. CLOSE ON: Stauffenberg's face - the reality of Africa taking the wind out of him. Over this we hear a familiar clicking of heels and:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stauffenberg's boots pound the floor as he rushes for the door, desperate to get out, barely able to breathe. At first he does not hear:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Colonel... COLONEL. A hand grabs his shoulder. Stauffenberg turns, ready to strike. He stops when he sees the Doctor holding a small, square box. Another sort medal perhaps?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want the damn th-                                The Doctor opens the box to reveal: A GLASS EYEBALL sitting atop a layer of satin, staring blankly back at Stauffenberg. Creepy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When will you be going back to the front? Beat. Stauffenberg just stares back at the eyeball.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not going to the front. I'm needed in Berlin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The city sleeps. An unsettling image knowing that, in war, quiet can turn to chaos in the blink of an eye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Soft knocking at the front door is further muffled by heavy black-out curtains. A YOUNG OFFICER enters the frame, dousing the lights, parting the curtains and opening the door to reveal a SHADOWY FIGURE on the stoop. The figure steps into the half light to reveal his fresh scars and eye-patch. And from the dark quiet of the foyer we CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chaos. The air is thick with cigar smoke and harsh words. A DOZEN MEN - some officers, some civilians - are fighting bitterly, everyone talking at once. Stauffenberg enters unnoticed, escorted in by the YOUNG OFFICER who immediately ducks out again. Stauffenberg scans the faces in the room. We recognize Olbricht and Tresckow. With them we find... A distinguished gentleman in his early sixties:

dialogues.speaker: THE MILITARY DISTRICT. FORCED OUT BY HITLER, 1938.
dialogues.text: Beside him is a rough-hewn, charismatic man despite his 59 years. A face millions might follow. He is: TITLES: DR. CARL GOERDELER - FORMER MAYOR OF LEIPZIG. RESIGNED IN PROTEST, 1937. And finally, a grandfatherly sort with surprisingly kind eyes, sitting outside the fight - tired and saddened by it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...He is not a man, he's a lunatic. He doesn't drink, he doesn't fuck. He has no weakness to exploit, no vice to manipulate. His only                             passion is complete control. How can you expect to reason with him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After this most recent failure I'd say we've no other choice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Confront Hitler now and you'll end up with piano wire for a neck-tie. Our only option is the central solution.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's a man like any other. Flesh and blood. Take him head on and-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TRESCKOW

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll say this for you, Doctor... You're certainly delusional enough to take Hitler's place. GOERDELER (eyes narrowing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When that day comes, I'll be sure to remember you. TRESCKOW

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I doubt you'll remember much of anything. GOERDELER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dammit, Tresckow- And the shouting resumes. It is Beck who finally sees Stauffenberg. He touches Tresckow's arm. He, in turn, nudges Olbricht and so on. A moment later, the room is silent, all eyes on the Colonel. Everyone is a little embarrassed. Olbricht clears his throat: OLBRICHT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gentlemen, may I present Colonel Stauffenberg. He's been reassigned to my office at the War Ministry. (to Stauffenberg)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Colonel, may I introduce- STAUFFENBERG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These men need no introduction. Beck stands, shaking Stauffenberg's hand. BECK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I apologize for this unfortunate... spectacle. On behalf of everyone, welc- But before he can finish, Beck is seized with a gravelly cough that sends an uncomfortable chill through the room. He is very ill. GOERDELER (to the others)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I haven't welcomed him. Not yet. Where does he stand? TRESCKOW

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For God's sake-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GOERDELER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (re: Stauffenberg) He's a field officer. He knows the army better than any of us. I want to hear his opinion. TRESCKOW                             (to Stauffenberg)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right. What do you think,                      Colonel? Confront Hitler, force him                to resign? Or the central solution?                But before Stauffenberg can answer:                       GOERDELER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Central Solution." You soldiers                   are all the same. Say what you                     mean.                                              WITZLEBEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a laugh coming from a                       politician.                                        GOERDELER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The army will follow diplomats                     before they follow assassins. TRESCKOW

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They follow a butcher now. What difference does it-                                STAUFFENBERG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What makes you think the army will                 follow you at all?                                 The room quiets down. Beck hides a slight smile. He       likes Stauffenberg already.

dialogues.speaker: STAUFFENBERG, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oust him, kill him. That isn't what                matters. How do you plan to take                   control of the government when                     Hitler is gone?                                    Silence. Then a wave of laughter. "The balls on this      guy."                                                     GOERDELER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I beg your pardon, Colonel, but you                are in the presence of men who                     would have been Hitler's inner                     circle. Instead we resigned. We put                our principles above personal gain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have the have the respect of the                       people. And the army.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With all respect, sir, you put too much faith in your popularity. (to Goerdeler, pointed)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All of you do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now see here, Colonel- STAUFFENBERG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You said yourself, I'm a field                            officer. You all may understand                           government, but I know the men. A                         great many of them may hate Hitler,                       but they all fear him - they fear                         Himmler, Goebbels, the whole of the                       Reich. That kind of fear won't just                       die with Hitler. And as for                               respect: the army, and the people,                        respect only one thing. Authority.                        And if just one man questions that                        authority, you can lose them all.                         (to Beck, pointed)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They were fooled into following                           Hitler... How will you fool them -                        force them - into following you?                          Pause. The conspirators look at one another again, unsure of how to answer. For Stauffenberg it is a dreadful revelation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A depressed Stauffenberg walks down the deserted night streets. Silent but for the echo of his footsteps. Eerie. Across the street, an OLD WOMAN peers nervously out her window. The instant Stauffenberg makes eye contact she steps back, drawing the curtains. Afraid. He approaches a cozy brick cottage - the Berlin home he shares with his brother, Berthold. He is surprised when he looks through the window to find FOUR CHILDREN laughing and playing - the sound of music on a phonograph. Bittersweet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the next house over, he catches sight of a TEENAGE BOY, the picture of Aryan youth, watching him suspiciously from the upstairs window. It seems everyone is watching everyone in Hitler's German.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stauffenberg comes through the front door, the sound of the phonograph blaring now. Meet the children: BERTHOLD (9), HEIMERAN (7), FRANZ (5), VALERIE (2). They chase one another around the house in their pajamas making such a racket that the phonograph skips. (It will do so throughout the scene.) The children see Stauffenberg and charge, screaming:

dialogues.speaker: PAPA.
dialogues.text: He scoops them up, one by one, and kisses them, instantly putting the day's events behind him. Berthold follows them into the room, smiling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to children)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing here? I thought I left you in Bamberg. (to Berthold)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a wonderful surprise. Thank you, brother.

dialogues.speaker: MAMA, COME DOWN. PAPA IS HERE. PAPA
dialogues.text: IS HERE. (Etc.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nina nervously fixes her hair in the mirror. LOOK DOWN TO REVEAL a small datebook with a smaller monthly calendar in the corner of the page. A red dot marks one date in particular, followed by black dots for each day that has passed since. She turns sideways, smoothing her dress over her belly. In every way she indicates to us that she is pregnant. She tucks the datebook under some sundries in her luggage and rushes down to greet her husband. We stay in the room, hearing her greet Stauffenberg O.S. Laughter at children's antics we cannot see. The phonograph skips. More laughter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We want to go see them in their happiness. Instead we linger on Stauffenberg's dresser - neat and orderly. We focus on a photograph of the family from happier times. Beside it is a small box containing a glass eye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stauffenberg and Nina dance with one another to the delight of the children. We gradually PUSH IN tight on their faces, watching an entire conversation take place without dialogue. Each has a secret the other can guess. Stauffenberg looks at Nina, then her belly, first realizing and then questioning. Nina smiles and nods. Stauffenberg hugs her, delighted, but his delight is tainted with worry. Then the tables turn. Nina looks at Stauffenberg, as if divining his secret. His face never changes - a statue with that same tainted smile. In her face we see slow, grim realization. She may not know exactly what is going on, but she knows it is something. She does her best to keep smiling for the children. After the longest of moments, she nods. "All right." Then she puts her head on his shoulder, hiding her fears. It is an important moment. Read it again, taking the time to picture it in your mind. Then leave it alone. Done right it's a beautiful scene about a man, his family and the fate of the world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nina reads a story to the children in the adjoining room - an idyllic scene. The sound of the phonograph is soft and constant. Stauffenberg picks at a late dinner, now adept at the use of only three fingers. Berthold sits across from him, deeply troubled by whatever conversation we have just missed. They speak in hushed tones.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean you quit? STAUFFENBERG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I came to join the Resistance, not some sewing circle of discarded generals and politicians.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BERTHOLD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beck is a just and capable man. As for Goerdeler, well, he's popular. He'll make a good Chancellor. STAUFFENBERG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like Hitler before him, yes? Lately I have to wonder if Germany is even fit to choose her own destiny. BERTHOLD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't blame the people for this. You have to see the beginning of something to know how it'll end. It's no different than a farmer watching the corn grow. One day it's over his head. STAUFFENBERG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Plenty of people thought- BERTHOLD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The greatest offenders are not the ones who thought better but the ones who sensed better. STAUFFENBERG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you trying to say? BERTHOLD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I seem to remember you telling me about reports from the Ukraine - the SS forcing Jews to dig their own graves. You said then that Hitler should be removed. An officer's duty, you said. What's changed? STAUFFENBERG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I said senior officers. The only men that can get to him.                            BERTHOLD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perhaps it doesn't matter that you succeed. Stauffenberg looks at Berthold like he is crazy, but:

dialogues.speaker: BERTHOLD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Perhaps it only matters that you try. Don't you see? Someone has to stand up and show the world that not all of us were like him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: STAUFFENBERG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Even if they could remove Hitler, they can't hope to seize power. For God's sake, they have no plan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then give them one. Find a way. He puts a hand on Stauffenberg's arm. BERTHOLD (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Evil happens when good men do nothing. Before Stauffenberg can answer, new music comes blasting from the phonograph O.S. The unmistakable sound of Wagner's Ride of the Valkyries. STAUFFENBERG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Children, that is far too- He is cut off by the appearance of his four children, all wearing cloaks made of bed sheets, pots for helmets and brandishing makeshift swords. They charge into the room, singing loudly and attacking their father. He does his best to defend himself with one hand. Their commotion causes the phonograph to skip. And you'd think that's where it ends. We even pull back, creating that effect. It takes a moment to notice the wailing sound we're suddenly hearing is not on the phonograph. Nina hears it first, then Stauffenberg and Berthold. Finally the children freeze and the phonograph skips without their help. The glasses on the table rattle. Now we hear the wailing quite clearly. A siren. STAUFFENBERG (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Air-raid. The adults herd the children out of the room. Muffled concussions cause the phonograph to skip frequently, turning Wagner's masterpiece into a stutter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The family rushes down the stairs, huddling in a corner - adults holding shivering children. The bombs are closer, louder. The Wagner, the siren, the explosions fray the nerves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stauffenberg reaches for Nina in the darkness, finding her belly. Her hand clamps around his - around their unborn child. BOOM. So close the children scream. Dust and debris fall from the ceiling. The needle rakes the phonograph upstairs going back to the beginning. CLOSE ON STAUFFENBERG - on his eye. His thoughts as the bombs fall all around his home - a moment of profound realization...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Move across the room to the phonograph, looking down at the 78 spinning on the turntable. The camera begins to turn until all the world around us is spinning and only the record is still. We read one word of the title of the 78 quite clearly: STAUFFENBERG (V.O.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Valkyrie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stauffenberg faces the top members of the Resistance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've already considered Valkyrie. It isn't suitable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not as it's currently written.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me. What is Valkyrie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Operation Valkyrie. Tresckow explains even as he studies Stauffenberg, curious. What does he have in mind? TRESCKOW (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Reserve Army has thousands of                        men all over the city - most of                          them not even in uniform. Valkyrie                       is top secret plan to mobilize                           those men in a national emergency.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: STAUFFENBERG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hitler designed it himself to crush any internal unrest if he's cut off or killed. GOERDELER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what use is that to us? STAUFFENBERG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The orders could be rewritten. A                few subtle changes would put those              reserve units completely under our              command. OLBRICHT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, of course, but- STAUFFENBERG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now what would the High Command do if they thought, say, the SS was staging a coup? OLBRICHT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They would declare a military state of emergency. TRESCKOW

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And initiate Operation Valkyrie. STAUFFENBERG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hitler's   own Reserve Army, using Hitler's   own plan and under our command,   would automatically seize power in   Berlin...                            GOERDELER                         (catching on)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: While we put a new government in                place. STAUFFENBERG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Precisely. It will seem as though we're fighting for Hitler                       Government, not against it.                     GOERDELER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But only if Hitler's dead.                      All eyes turn to Goerdeler. Here we go.

dialogues.speaker: GOERDELER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That is what you're saying, isn't it? The central solution.

dialogues.speaker: GOERDELER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: How else will you make people believe the SS is trying to seize power? STAUFFENBERG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm afraid it's the only way. GOERDELER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm disappointed in you, Colonel. I thought a man of your background would appreciate a more- STAUFFENBERG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm a soldier first, an aristocrat second. GOERDELER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, but- STAUFFENBERG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you're neither, Doctor. Now if you want to be Chancellor, you'll do as you're told. A moment of tension. Humiliated, Goerdeler nods. But he won't ever forget this... BECK (to Tresckow)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can this plan be made to work? TRESCKOW

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rewriting the order is one thing - distributing it is another. A bomb can be disarmed, recovered if it fails. In this case we'd be willfully circulating written evidence of high treason. (thinks)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the best idea we've heard yet. OLBRICHT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is one... small problem. TRESCKOW (realizing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fromm... GOERDELER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who is Fromm?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Commander of the Home Army. Olbricht can put the reserve troops on alert, but only Fromm can actually initiate Valkyrie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can we get to him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's a careerist pig.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But one who's gone as high as he can go in Hitler's Army. It's no secret he's not happy about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perhaps if we offered him a key position in the new regime he could be made to see the light.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We don't seem to have a choice. Without Fromm there is no Valkyrie. (to Olbricht and Stauffenberg) Get him. We end on Goerdeler, a look of concern on his face.

dialogues.speaker: FRIEDRICH FROMM.
dialogues.text: MUTED SHOUTS from O.S. Someone is getting reamed. Fromm's adjutant, LIEUTENANT FRANZ HERBER - a young, dedicated soldier - sits at his desk, trying to ignore the screaming from the other room in between stolen glances at... PULL BACK TO REVEAL: Stauffenberg and Olbricht waiting patiently, sitting across from: MAJOR JOHN VON FREYEND, a dutiful Nazi whose face we immediately don't like. He smiles coldly, taking pleasure in the shouting O.S. He stares at Stauffenberg, studying him, making us nervous. Fromm's door finally opens and A BIGGER THAN LIFE NAZI storms out.

dialogues.speaker: OF STAFF.
dialogues.text: Freyend stands, holding Keitel's hat and coat for him. A perfect toady.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a woman, Fromm. And a fat one at that. I'd have you sent to the front if I didn't think you'd surrender just to be Montgomery's whore. Keitel storms out, leaving a pall. Freyend gives Stauffenberg a last once-over and follows. Beat:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The... General will see you now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stauffenberg and Olbricht step inside to find:

dialogues.speaker: GERMAN RESERVE ARMY.
dialogues.text: The haggard Fromm sits at his desk, rubbing his temples. Stauffenberg and Olbricht share a confident look. Surely this guy hates the High Command. Without looking up to see them:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it you want? Olbricht hesitates. Fromm looks up. FROMM (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, Olbricht? Speak up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wanted to introduce you to our new man - Colonel Stauffenberg.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah yes - the hero from Africa. I'd offer my hand but you might not give it back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd say the General's lost more important things this morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Freeze. But after a tense beat, Fromm relaxes and laughs, taking a cigarette from a box on his desk and nudging it toward them. FROMM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About time they put a man with balls in this office. Have a seat. (to Olbricht)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You too, if you must. They sit. Fromm lights a cigarette, leans back and exhales a cloud of smoke. We let things sit for awhile. The game of recruitment is about to begin and no one is sure where to start. The longer the quiet, the more awkward things seem. Finally: FROMM (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They tell me you're critical of the war, Colonel. Not that you don't seem to have good reason. STAUFFENBERG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am critical of losing the war, General. All wars - as in Africa - are lost through indecision. FROMM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the field, you mean. He's baiting Stauffenberg to talk shit about Hitler. STAUFFENBERG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In Berlin. FROMM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I take it that's why you're here. To make decisions. STAUFFENBERG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've made my decision, General. I`m here to help others make theirs. Stauffenberg makes no attempt to shade his delivery. He is quite clearly indicating that he means more. Fromm knows it, but he's being coy. FROMM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They say when there's no clear option, one should do nothing. STAUFFENBERG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're at war. We must act.                          Sometimes... rashly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FROMM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just what sort of rash action did you have in mind, Colonel? STAUFFENBERG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That would be a decision for the Supreme Military Commander. Fromm is getting the message. He takes a deep drag. FROMM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Supreme Commander, you say. STAUFFENBERG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Second only to the Chancellor. FROMM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If only I were that man... This war would be going quite differently. OLBRICHT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We were thinking the very same thing. Fromm frowns at Olbricht. This was a bit too obvious. Stauffenberg shoots Olbricht a look. "What the hell are you doing?" Fromm casually stamps out his cigarette in the ashtray and picks up the telephone. Olbricht and Stauffenberg steel their nerves - certain they are going to be reported. But Fromm doesn't dial. Instead, to our relief, he disconnects the line. When he is certain that it is dead: FROMM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't need to remind you that we've all sworn an oath. That said, I'm going to forget we had this conversation with the understanding that such speak will never occur under this roof again. Am I clear?

dialogues.speaker: STAUFFENBERG/OLBRICHT
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell   your friends that I always come   down on the right side. And as long   as the FГјhrer is alive, you know   what side that is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FROMM (CONT'D) (raising his hand)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Heil Hitler.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (trying to be upbeat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think that went rather well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes... Quite.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A car loaded with luggage. Stauffenberg hugs his children, one by one, before placing them inside. Then he turns to face Nina. As always, there is much to be said that they cannot say. She gently touches the silver chain around his neck, the ring and the cross she gave him. They embrace tightly and kiss. She gets in the car, looking at him through the back window as she is driven away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Darkness. As our eyes adjust we realize we are in the middle of the woods. Is this a dream? A nightmare? We are drawn toward a flickering light in the distance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From out of the darkness comes a candle held by a nervous, almost mousy young woman, FRAULEIN VON OVEN. Walking just behind her is Tresckow. He carries a small but heavy case in one hand. They come to a clearing in the woods and find a strange sight. In the center is a tree stump surrounded by papers, including the original orders for OPERATION VALKYRIE, next to a leather valise marked with the seal of the Reich. The orders have been meticulously annotated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Were you followed?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fraulein Oven gasps. Tresckow turns, pistol drawn. The tip of his barrel comes up just inches from Stauffenberg's eyepatch. Stauffenberg smiles, emerging from the shadows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dammit, Stauffenberg. You scared me half to death.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll be closer than that before we're finished.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wearing white gloves, Fraulein Oven opens the case Tresckow brought, revealing a portable typewriter. She carefully feeds a sheet of crisp parchment into the machine and sets the margins carefully. Pause. Then she starts typing with remarkable speed. (Note: The sound of typing runs throughout the scene, punctuated by the crack of the carriage return - each time a little louder.) Stauffenberg and Tresckow carefully pore over the Valkyrie orders, scribbling copious notes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looking this over, I'm not satisfied that the Reserve Army is enough to shut down Berlin completely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (handing over papers)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I've been giving that some thought. We should include any field units that are home on leave. Before Tresckow can respond, more papers: STAUFFENBERG (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've also drawn up an outline for orders to streamline combat groups in order to quietly concentrate forces at vital points - state and government buildings, of course, but also the radio and newspapers. More papers. Tresckow can barely keep up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: STAUFFENBERG (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Combat groups will be reorganized as reinforced grenadier regiments. One or two of them can be quickly mobilized, eliminating the usual six hour lag. We blitz the government quarter, arrest all Ministers and Party leaders, surround all SS and police barracks. Any officers who resist will be arrested... or shot. CRACK. A carriage return as loud as a rifle-shot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A truck full of soldiers roars past. Stauffenberg, Tresckow and Fraulein Oven walk across a dimly lit bridge on a foggy night in Berlin, stopping in the middle. Stauffenberg carries a leather valise with the Valkyrie orders, Tresckow carries the typewriter case. They stop at the center of the bridge, looking around carefully. No one is in sight, but anyone could be watching from the shadows. Eerie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the Fraulein)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If anyone comes to you, play                         ignorant. Just tell them-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll tell that I was serving the                     German people. Then I'll tell them                   to go to hell.                                       Both men smile, a bit taken aback. Von Oven shakes each man's hand and walks away, swallowed up by the darkness. When she is gone:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To Operation Valkyrie.                               Stauffenberg nods. Tresckow heaves the typewriter case over the railing and into the water below. SPLASH. They watch in silence as the water settles, then:

dialogues.speaker: TRESCKOW, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I've been transferred to the front.                 STAUFFENBERG                            (shocked)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why didn't you tell me?                             TRESCKOW

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you have stayed?                              Obviously not. Then it occurs to Stauffenberg. STAUFFENBERG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you think Fromm reported us?                     TRESCKOW

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's more likely just... an                         unfortunate coincidence. Anyway it                  doesn't matter. You wrote the                       orders. You know them better than                   anyone.                                             STAUFFENBERG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't mean to say-                              TRESCKOW

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm appointing you military leader                  of the Resistance. Beck agrees.                     STAUFFENBERG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But Olbricht-                                       TRESCKOW

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We both know Olbricht hasn't the                    wit or the spine. No. It's you.                     A million thoughts are running through Stauffenberg's mind. Fear. Anxiety. But he knows what he must do.

dialogues.speaker: TRESCKOW, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: One more thing. You were right what                 you said that first night. It's not                 enough to kill Hitler. We need to                   isolate his chain of command. The                   slightest confusion could crush us.                 We need to be certain that no                       conflicting orders get out after                    the flash.                                          Stauffenberg considers this for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That greatly limits our options of                       where and when to make our move,                         but it's the only way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How will you do it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perhaps it's better I don't say.                         Pause. A sad smile and nod from Tresckow, a moment ago he was in charge. Now he has no clearance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God promised Abraham that he would                       not destroy Sodom if he could find                       just ten righteous men.                                  He puts a hand on Stauffenberg's shoulder. TRESCKOW (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have a feeling that for Germany                        it may come down to one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A wild party - a small band, German officers, plenty of women. In stark contrast, two GESTAPO MEN sip coffee at a corner table, keeping a watchful eye on the crowd. A WAITER carries a tray of drinks to a rowdy group in the corner who are immersed in the denial common to Berlin these days. The Waiter serves carefully, making sure one particular drink goes to:

dialogues.speaker: SIGNAL CORPS.
dialogues.text: The group toasts and downs their booze. CLOSE ON: Fellgiebel's smile suddenly fades. He looks into his glass, his good mood vanishing. He politely excuses himself over the noise of the rowdy mob and heads for the bathroom. He looks ill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fellgiebel walks to the sink and dumps what is left of his drink in the basin. CLOSE ON: Mingling among the melting chunks of ice is a GLASS EYE staring back at him. He scowls in the mirror at Stauffenberg, waiting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You realize how close I am to Hitler. With one word I could have the Gestapo make you disappear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why haven't you then? Fellgiebel checks the stalls to make sure they are empty. Stauffenberg collects his glass eye from the sink, dabbing it dry on a hand towel. STAUFFENBERG (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: None of my associates know we've been talking if that's what you're afraid of.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you know. And when the SS catch you, they'll pull you apart like warm bread. It'll be a crime just to have known you then. I warn you. If it means protecting myself, I will expose you. Do not try to contact me again. Fellgiebel heads for the door but stops on:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't report me. Maybe if you had when I first approached you, you'd have been keeping your oath. But now you're just as guilty as-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you think that makes me a sympathizer, eh? You give a man the choice of betraying a fellow officer or his FГјhrer and assume his actions will show you his heart. It's not that simple.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: STAUFFENBERG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is to me. FELLGIEBEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For the last time, don't push me to make a decision. STAUFFENBERG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have no choice. It's clear now that without you we have no hope of success. Pause. Fellgiebel's silence speaks volumes.

dialogues.speaker: STAUFFENBERG, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You want us to succeed. Don't you? FELLGIEBEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what if you do, eh? What then? Will you be any different from Hitler? What of his Reich, his people, the very momentum of history? Will all of that let you be something he isn't? STAUFFENBERG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. FELLGIEBEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There it is. STAUFFENBERG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But my pregnant wife, our four children, the Germany I first swore to defend... They demand that I be something different. They demand that I fight for their future even if it means... And for a moment his voice breaks and he chokes back what may be tears.

dialogues.speaker: STAUFFENBERG, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Even if it means that I never see them again. In that moment we see a side of Stauffenberg we were starting to doubt existed. We see his humanity. This puts Fellgiebel in his place. He adjusts his tie and we see the wedding ring on his finger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: STAUFFENBERG (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Action is inevitable. As are the consequences. When they come for me I'll do what I can to hide what you knew and when you knew it. (stepping closer now)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But don't delude yourself. You were involved in a crime against your country long before you met me. There's still time to redeem yourself. Only God can judge you now. BANG. The door bursts open, startling them both. But it is only a DRUNKEN OFFICER and a YOUNG WOMAN looking for some privacy. DRUNKEN OFFICER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you two finished or just getting started? The woman laughs. Stauffenberg walks out past them, leaving Fellgiebel with Hitler's finest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What first catches our eye is the enormous portrait of Hitler looming over Stauffenberg's desk. Stauffenberg sits before a mountain of paperwork, surrounded on all sides by a flurry of SECRETARIES and AIDES. He looks up to find: Olbricht hovering in the doorway with that look that says, "We need to talk." Stauffenberg clearly doesn't have the time. He sighs. STAUFFENBERG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leave us, please. The staff instantly exits - a well-oiled machine. Stauffenberg unplugs the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You play the part of bureaucrat beautifully.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the only time I can relax.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OLBRICHT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a man here to interview as your adjutant. STAUFFENBERG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adjut- What for? OLBRICHT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No one told you? (obviously not)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've been promoted Chief of Staff for the Reserve Army. Some men might find a promotion to be good news. Not Stauffenberg. STAUFFENBERG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For Christ's sake. Don't I have enough to do? OLBRICHT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Unfortunately, your nocturnal activities don't count as service to the Reich. STAUFFENBERG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll refuse the promotion. OLBRICHT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll do no such thing. STAUFFENBERG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dammit, I can't handle the work I already- OLBRICHT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is an opportunity we could never have dreamed of. You're in the inner circle now - with genuine access to Hitler, his advisors, his schedule... We need this. STAUFFENBERG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're not ready. We're moving too fast. OLBRICHT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not half as fast as the Allies. An invasion is coming, Colonel. Any day now. We must act and we must act soon.

dialogues.speaker: OLBRICHT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Tresckow may have left you in charge of the "central solution,"                     but in this world I still outrank you. You will accept the appointment. Is that understood? Stauffenberg nods, grudgingly.

dialogues.speaker: OLBRICHT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Now. The new man is waiting outside. He comes highly recommended. He might even be an ideal candidate. STAUFFENBERG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For what? OLBRICHT (smiling)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We still need an assassin. Olbricht leaves. Stauffenberg lets this sink in. He takes a seat and goes back to work. After a moment: A HANDSOME SOLDIER (36) quietly enters. TITLES: LIEUTENANT WERNER VON HAEFTEN - RESERVIST. WOUNDED DURING THE RUSSIAN CAMPAIGN. Haeften clicks his heels and offers the Nazi salute, but before he can say the words: STAUFFENBERG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Be seated. Thrown, Haeften sits. Stauffenberg continues writing, ignoring him. Haeften looks up at the portrait of Hitler, startled when Stauffenberg finally speaks:

dialogues.speaker: STAUFFENBERG, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Do you know how this war will end, Haeften? The portrait will be un- hung... And the man will be hung. Stauffenberg looks up - looking for a reaction to such frank and treasonous talk. He gets none. He sighs, too tired to play games.

dialogues.speaker: STAUFFENBERG, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Bottom line. I'm engaged in high treason with all means available to me. Can I count you in?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And the strangest thing - a reaction no one would suspect - Haeften relaxes, almost sighs, like someone who has at long last found a home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For anything, sir. Anything at all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anything is a very dangerous word.

dialogues.speaker: TITLES
dialogues.text: NEWSREEL FOOTAGE OF D-DAY. Allied forces invade Normandy. The liberation of Europe has begun. But this is not the D-Day you learned about in history class. This is a German newsreel. Nazi spin. In it, Hitler's forces have nothing to fear. NEWSCASTER (V.O.) (subtitles)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Allied Forces have blundered into the trap awaiting them on the beaches of Normandy - heroically repelled by the combined might of the German Army. It is a glorious day for the Reich. At long last the craven enemy has come to Europe to face their inevitable defeat at the hands of-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Five thousand ships, one-hundred thousand men from the combined Allied forces. Haeften and Stauffenberg ride in a sedan. Stauffenberg is in profile the entire time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about the Panzer divisions in-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They were never dispatched. Word is Hitler took a sleeping pill. His staff was afraid to wake him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: First Africa, now France.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Russians bearing down from the East.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sometimes I wonder if Hitler's real aim is to leave nothing but scorched earth for all of Europe. Stauffenberg rubs his forehead. The car stops. SOLDIERS are waiting outside. Stauffenberg gets out of the car wearing an ornate dress uniform and carrying a leather valise. He has arrived at a meeting of great importance. He turns to face Haeften directly and we are surprised to see both of his eyes - for an instant the young lion he once was. But a closer look is unsettling - we see the faint scarring, one eye glowing and alive, the other cloudy and dead. His glass eye. Stauffenberg only wore it on special occasions. This is one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe this is a blessing in disguise. Maybe he'll finally listen to reason - consider a truce while he still can.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll see if I can't convince him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Est. Hitler's forboding southern headquarters. TITLES: THE BERGHOF. 7 JUNE 1944. Stauffenberg walks up a flight of wide marble stairs - at the top he sees a group of WAITING ADJUTANTS quietly smoking cigarettes - a clique of devoted Nazis. In the group is Major Freyend, the wormy officer we saw outside Fromm's office. He watches Stauffenberg pass, aloof. We hate him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just then Stauffenberg is greeted by TWO SS OFFICERS who move to physically search him - one his body, the other his valise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't need to search him. ANGLE ON: Fromm's adjutant, Lt. Herber approaches, waving off the SS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Colonel Stauffenberg is an honored guest. The hero of Africa. The SS officers stand down. Herber and Stauffenberg share a friendly smile, about to speak when Fromm walks up on them:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For God's sake, Stauffenberg, you're- He pauses, clearly caught off guard when he sees Stauffenberg with two eyes. FROMM (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... they're waiting for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stauffenberg and Fromm enter to the last thing we would expect. Laughter. Drunken laughter. PULL BACK TO REVEAL: THE BIG SIX. Hitler and five men - some of them almost caricatures, their features so distinct. The first man we recognize as Keitel - the general who reamed Fromm. The others we know from history and TITLES: MINISTER ALBERT SPEER - ARCHITECT FOR THE NEW REICH.

dialogues.speaker: ENLIGHTENMENT AND PROPAGANDA.
dialogues.text: REICHSFГњHRER HEINRICH HIMMLER - HEAD OF THE SS AND GESTAPO.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have arrived in the sanctum sanatorium of Nazi Germany on the day after the Normandy invasion. But you would never know the tide of the war had just turned against Germany. A series of situation maps are scattered before them, ignored. Only Speer seems to be reserved, smiling politely but clearly tuned into the present reality. Looking closer at Goering we see he is wearing heavy make-up - adding to the already surreal nature of the scene. It is also the first time we are allowed a clear, unobstructed view of Hitler. FROMM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mein FГјhrer... I wish to present Colonel Claus von Stauffenberg - our new Chief of General Staff for the Replacement Army. The laughter stops. Hitler and his cronies turn toward Stauffenberg, looking him over. Hitler stands and crosses to him. Fromm meets him first, whispering in the FГјhrer's ear - perhaps reminding him who Stauffenberg is. Hitler nods: "Ah yes." He takes Stauffenberg's left hand with both of his. We are surprised by his charm. HITLER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: May I say, I am honored to meet a hero who has sacrificed so much for Germany. If only more of my officers were like you. Hitler's cronies smile despite the subtle insult to themselves. To make it worse, Hitler turns to them.

dialogues.speaker: HITLER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Let this man stand as an example to all of you. He is the ideal German officer. Fromm nervously clears his throat. FROMM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mein FГјhrer, we have asked Stauffenberg here today so that he might brief us on mobilizing troops from the Home Army to support those in Normandy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hmmm? Oh yes, Normandy. That will no longer be necessary. General Goering has assured me that Normandy is under control. Stauffenberg's good eye flickers. "Are you insane? Normandy is a catastrophe." Another glance at the situation map shows Allied forces over-running. But the painted-on smiles of Hitler's nodding cronies promote the lie. No one has the courage to tell Hitler anything close to the truth. Somewhere in their eyes is the fear that someone will.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mein FГјhrer, if I may... The situation in Normandy is-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're dismissed, Stauffenberg.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Send your man home, Fromm. Then bring us some brandy. Fromm is stung - a man of his rank being treated like a waiter. Stauffenberg steps back, clicks his heels and salutes, just managing to say:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Heil Hitler. Hitler half waves, walking slowly back to his seat. Fromm and Stauffenberg leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fromm escorts a visibly shaken Stauffenberg to his waiting vehicle. Haeften opens the car door for Stauffenberg to get in. Fromm leans in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know what you've got brewing and I don't want to know... But when the music stops, I'd be much obliged if Keitel should find himself without a chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is Fromm saying he's in? Is Keitel's death a condition? Hard to say and meant to be. Before Stauffenberg can inquire, Fromm slams the door shut and returns to the madness inside the Berghof.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stauffenberg leans back in his seat, mentally calculating his next step.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're all insane. Every one of them except for Speer, and he's nothing but an architect. Stauffenberg puts on his eyepatch before removing his glass eye. He polishes it with a cloth and now it stares at him from his gloved hand. A conscience. STAUFFENBERG (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell Beck we've found our assassin... (off Haeften's confused look) I'll do it myself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We find ourselves in an empty church. Beck is seated in a pew staring straight ahead. Stauffenberg sits directly behind him. They can't risk being seen together. They speak in hushed tones. The first thing we notice is how weak and ill Beck looks. He struggles to hide a persistent cough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Out of the question. It won't work. We need you here in Berlin. STAUFFENBERG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who else, then? Who can even get as close? Beck knows there is no other choice. STAUFFENBERG (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Valkyrie is very clear. Once the order is given, the Reserve Army                         will automatically seize control of the government with or without me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Orders are not enough. They need a man to follow. The right man. Pause. Stauffenberg knows he's right. The fucking pressure. He thinks for a moment, then with a sigh: STAUFFENBERG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Olbricht will oversee operations in my absence. I can be back in Berlin three hours after Hitler is- Stauffenberg shuts up, lowering his head in prayer as a CLERGYMAN passes. Once they are again alone:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Three very crucial hours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We both know there's no other way. Beck nods, resigned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll tell the others- As if on cue, Beck loses control of his cough. Stauffenberg leans forward, handing him a handkerchief and putting a reassuring hand on his shoulder until the old man's hacking subsides. BECK (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm afraid whatever the outcome, I won't be there to see it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nonsense. You're stronger than you think. You might just be the strongest one of all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Est. The sound of children at play takes us to:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Once again, the scene idyllic. The Stauffenberg children play football in the distance. Stauffenberg himself is out of uniform for the first time since the hospital, but he does not seem relaxed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nina sits across from him, half-reading a book, half talking to her husband. Stauffenberg cannot hear a word she is saying - he is miles away. He looks over at his children. One would never suspect that Germany has waged a calamitous war and that the country is facing total devastation. NINA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...After that I thought I'd take the children to the country for a few days to see my- Claus? He snaps out of his thoughts. "Hmmm?" NINA (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you heard a word I said? STAUFFENBERG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The country... (thinking)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nina. Listen. I want you to delay your trip. Just for a while. She wants to ask, he wants to tell her. Finally: NINA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Does this have something to do with... your work? STAUFFENBERG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I would just be more comfortable knowing where you are - until I'm back from Berlin. Things will be different then. I promise. Long pause. Once again, a couple who know each other well enough to not have to say things plainly. Nina is worried but strong. NINA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long until... until we see you? STAUFFENBERG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A few days. If all goes well. Then we can travel as a family. NINA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And if things... don't go well? He hesitates.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: STAUFFENBERG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love you, Nina.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I love you... What-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PAPA, COME AND PLAY WITH US. (Etc.) The children kick the ball toward Stauffenberg - the one sport he can play. He is about to say something to Nina, but she cuts him off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go be with your children. Stauffenberg stands, touching Nina's cheek and kissing her forehead. We stay on her as he joins the children. She watches them play together, seeing her husband laughing for the first time in a long while. Her eyes well with tears - a mixture of happiness and anguish. Too good to last, too much to bear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haeften, Olbricht and Stauffenberg stand around a table giving their undivided attention to:

dialogues.speaker: REPLACEMENT UNDER OLBRICHT.
dialogues.text: He empties the contents of two tawny leather briefcases onto the table: Along with a crude drawing covered with calculations he produces two brick-like lumps wrapped in butcher paper, two small caps and two thin metal cylinders.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two 975 gram packs of plastic-W. Enough explosive to cripple a panzer. (pointing to caps)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your detonators. (pointing to cylinders)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your fuses. British time pencils. This acid capsule is your trigger. Stauffenberg carefully studies the items before him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MERTZ (CONT'D)
