dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When you're ready to arm, attach the detonator to the bottom of the time pencil, like so... (demonstrating)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Insert the entire device into either end of the plastic-W, crush the acid capsule and you're live. When the acid eats through the wire holding back the trigger spring... Well... You'll want to be very far away. OLBRICHT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What if they search your bag? STAUFFENBERG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm one of the inner circle now. They'll make sure I am who I am. Beyond that, they won't touch me. (to Mertz)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How much time do I have? MERTZ

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Theoretically there's a 30-minute delay. But with the kind of heat you can expect at the Wolf's Lair, I'd give you 10, 15 minutes tops. HAEFTEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's... hardly precise.                             MERTZ

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is state of the art. You can have small or precise. Not both. OLBRICHT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Might this be just a little too small? MERTZ

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The explosion won't do the killing. The air in the room will. He points to the drawing - an overhead sketch of: MERTZ (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hitler's bunker is constructed of reenforced concrete. A steel door, no windows. Just one of these explosives in a space like that will cause tremendous air pressure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MERTZ (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Enough to instantly kill everyone present. The second charge will be entirely redundant. OLBRICHT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course, I'm all for redundancy. However... If, by some miracle, Hitler does survive, what then? STAUFFENBERG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have an inside man at the Wolf's Lair in communications. He'll notify you immediately following the flash and then sever all contact with the outside world. The others are stunned. OLBRICHT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just how did you manage that? STAUFFENBERG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's my job, isn't it? While Hitler's inner circle is still regrouping, you will initiate Valkyrie and seize control in Paris and Berlin. Even if Hitler survives, we'll have momentum.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Olbricht)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But as   you said yourself it would take a   miracle. Anyone in that bunker   when just one of these goes off is   not coming out alive. Haeften places the items back in the briefcases. OLBRICHT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Himmler is expected to be at the meeting as well. Don't proceed unless you can get them both. STAUFFENBERG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That could be difficult. OLBRICHT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why kill a madman just to have a lunatic take his place? STAUFFENBERG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is Goerdeler's idea, isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The members are in total agreement on this.                                                Stauffenberg chews on this, pissed. Then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fucking politicians. I'll hold off                      if the decision is unanimous. And I                     want another man on the committee.                      A soldier.                                              A soldier himself, Olbricht is insulted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And just who this soldier be?                           Stauffenberg glances at Mertz, sizing him, up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pointing to Mertz)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Him?                                                    Mertz's eyes widen. "Me?" But Stauffenberg and Haeften pick up their briefcases and leave without another word. Assassins. Olbricht reaches for the phone and dials. OLBRICHT (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is General Olbricht. Order the Guard Battalion and all Army Schools near Berlin to take up march readiness. Stand by for Operation Valkyrie. CLACK-CLACK-CLACK-CLACK-CLACK...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A small, bunker-like room serves as the hub of all military communications. The walls are lined with chattering teletype machines and their OPERATORS. CLOSE ON: One teletype in particular. The words are clicking by quickly but we clearly make out: STAND BY FOR OPERATION VALKYRIE...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One SERGEANT HELM leans in, reading it, curious. He tears the sheet out of the teletype and takes it to: The officious LIEUTENANT HAANS - officer in charge. He likes his job and how well he does it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (handing over the order)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lieutenant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This order is calling the Reserve Army for some sort of stand-by action... in Berlin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shrugs)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looks like a drill of some kind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Valkyrie? I've never heard of that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Send the order through, Sergeant. A SHRILL WHISTLE and a WAILING SIREN take us to...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shots of scattered elements of the Reserve Army coming together, taking shape: RESERVISTS and CADETS, from all walks of life, rush to their homes, hastily trading their civilian clothes for uniforms.

dialogues.speaker: TITLES
dialogues.text: Stauffenberg and Haeften board a waiting courier plane, preparing for departure. Both are clutching their briefcases, faces like stone. Stauffenberg is dressed once again in his ornate, formal attire - his patch gone, glass eye in place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AIR SIRENS wail. A SCULPTED EAGLE AND SWASTIKA loom over a large pillared stronghold. From out of the surrounding barracks, RESERVE SOLDIERS scramble to march readiness, assembling on the center parade grounds, awaiting orders. Vehicles move into place along the perimeter. All in all, a well-oiled machine.

dialogues.speaker: THE BERLIN COMMANDANT
dialogues.text: HASE - issuing the alert signal. AIR SIRENS wail. RESERVE SOLDIERS scramble into readiness. Vehicles move into place - a well-oiled machine. We focus on two officers in particular: MAJOR OTTO ERNST REMER, Commander of the Deutschland Guard Battalion, and SECOND LIEUTENANT DR. HANS HAGEN. Loyal Nazis both.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you suppose this is all about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Probably just a drill. But Remer doesn't seem convinced. Remember him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shots of Stauffenberg and Haeften deplaning/getting into a waiting car/slowly making their way to their destination. Finally, they arrive at:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Est. A 625 acre compound hidden deep in the mosquito infested forests of Wilhelmsdorf. Security is tight - barbed wire fencing, checkpoints, flak towers, machine gun nests, trenches, land mines.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The car carrying Stauffenberg and Haeften arrives at the first security checkpoint. TWO GUARDS check identity papers and confiscate pistols from Haeften and The Driver. Stauffenberg boldly extends his valise to one of the Guards, but rather than reach for it, the young soldier snaps to attention and raises his hand in a Nazi salute, eyes straight ahead, stone-like. A drone. After an awkward pause:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the Driver)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Drive on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON STAUFFENBERG'S BAG. A series of JUMP CUTS follow the bag through the extensive security layers one must endure before getting to the meeting. ID is checked frequently. The bags, not once. The men here are Hitler's inner circle, after all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Finally, Stauffenberg and Haeften are escorted toward the bunker where the meeting will be held. Pausing, Stauffenberg looks back over his shoulder to find: THE COMMUNICATIONS HUT - through the open door of the small shack we see a mass of radios and telegraphs. A LONE FIGURE stands outside, smoking a cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispering to Haeften)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your man? Yes. And it is none other than GENERAL ERICH FELLGIEBEL, the man Stauffenberg confronted in the bathroom at the Officers' Club so long ago. He and Stauffenberg share a long, intense stare. Finally, Fellgiebel nods, dropping his cigarette and crushing it with his boot. He's in. Stauffenberg and Haeften head inside the impervious bunker through the heavy steel door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stauffenberg and Haeften find themselves in a cramped, hot, windowless room filled with VARIOUS OFFICERS waiting around a large conference table. Silence. A moment later, Hitler enters - Keitel and Fromm follow close behind. Heels click in unison. Keitel starts the meeting, but Stauffenberg isn't listening. While all eyes follow Hitler, Stauffenberg watches the door, scanning the faces in the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispering)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Himmler. Where is Himmler? Haeften doesn't see him either. Shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Now for the first order of business. Fromm, I believe you will brief us on blocking divisions for the Eastern Front... Stauffenberg silently excuses himself from the room. We hold on his briefcase. Remember where he left it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The phone rings. A waiting Mertz grabs it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: General Olbricht's Office. (suddenly nervous)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hold the line. (to Olbricht)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stauffenberg says Himmler's not at the briefing. He wants to proceed. All color drains from Olbricht's face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Call Beck. He leaves. Mertz rolls his eyes and dials a second phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beck and Goerdeler sit impatiently by the telephone, waiting for any word on the assassination and impending coup. When the telephone RINGS:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beck. He presses the receiver tightly to his ear, a look of concern washing over his face. He turns to Goerdeler. BECK (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Himmler is not in the briefing. Goerdeler's reaction is vintage politician. Blank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON A CIGARETTE. We watch as Stauffenberg smokes, waits, looks at his watch - the sounds of the meeting going on behind him. He drops his cigarette and we see a pile of three more. He has been waiting while the others deliberate. Finally: MERTZ (ON PHONE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They say no. Wait. (Note: Intercut between Mertz and Stauffenberg.) Stauffenberg is furious. He calms himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you say? Pause. Mertz looks around, makes sure he is alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I say do it. Stauffenberg hangs up the phone. The moment of truth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stauffenberg quietly slips back into the briefing unnoticed. He freezes: CLOSE ON: The spot where Stauffenberg left his briefcase. Remember? Well it's gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks around frantically. Some officers notice him. Tension mounts. He gets Haeften's attention.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (mouthing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My briefcase. Before Haeften can answer, Fromm shoots them both a glare. "What the hell are you doing?"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Gentleman. You are dismissed. And like that, the briefing has ended. Stauffenberg is sickened - the opportunity lost. Hitler exits, walking right past him. Keitel and the rest file out. The last to leave is Fromm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That call better have been important. Stauffenberg turns, coming face-to-face with Freyend, Keitel's hateful toady. He holds the missing briefcase. For a moment we're sure the jig is up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your bag... Colonel. He hands it over and leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A military sedan skids to a stop outside the Guard Battalion headquarters. Olbricht jumps from the car, racing to get General Hase's attention. LARGE FORMATIONS of soldiers stand at attention in the hot sun, awaiting orders.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispering)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell is going on? My men have been standing here for an hour. I don't know what to tell them. CLOSE ON REMER (the officer we told you to remember) standing before the ranks. He eyes Hase and Olbricht suspiciously, trying to hear what they are saying. After a moment, Hase addresses the men.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HASE (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At ease, gentlemen. Olbricht addresses the men, trying unsuccessfully to hide his nerves. OLBRICHT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This has been a drill. You're all to be commended for your quick response. Dismissed. Pause. The men linger, confused until:

dialogues.speaker: HEIL HITLER.
dialogues.text: SOLDIERS

dialogues.speaker: HEIL HITLER.
dialogues.text: And the men fall out, nowhere to go so they just light up and shoot the shit. Hagen approaches Remer. HAGEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did I tell you? A drill. But Remer is not so sure. The way he stares at Olbricht makes us nervous. CLOSE ON: Olbricht sees Remer looking at him, making note of the esteemed KNIGHT'S CROSS pinned to Remer's uniform. Olbricht leans toward Hase. OLBRICHT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That man there. Who is he? HASE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Major Remer? He commands the Deutschland Guard Battalion. What about him? OLBRICHT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get rid of him. HASE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Remer? Don't worry about him. He's an order taker. To the bone. Ah yes... But whose orders?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As usual, Lt. Herber sits at his desk and, as usual, he tries to ignore: MUTED SHOUTS through Fromm's office door. PULL BACK TO REVEAL Stauffenberg and Olbricht waiting. They sit across from, Freyend. A beat later, Keitel storms out of Fromm's office, his face red with anger. Deja vu. When Keitel and Freyend are gone: Herber looks up from his desk with a nervous smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The General will see you now. Stauffenberg and Olbricht stand, hats in hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How dare you put the Reserve Army on standby without my knowledge. You damn near cost me my commission. What in God's name made you think you even had the authority?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was only a drill. An exercise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DON'T LIE, OLBRICHT. Not to me. We both know it was no fucking drill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: General, if I may-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You may not, Colonel. You may not do anything. Because now you've not only shown me you can't deliver, you've painted a target on my back. If I so much as sense you trying to move the Reserve Army again, I'll personally have you both arrested. Do I make myself abundantly clear? STAUFFENBERG/OLBRICHT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Heil Hitler.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Heil Hitler. But Stauffenberg turns to leave without answering.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll hear you say it, Colonel. Stauffenberg stops, glaring at Fromm with his one eye. He squares his shoulders, clicks his heels loudly and delivers a downright Nazi-like:

dialogues.speaker: HEIL HITLER.
dialogues.text: Still managing to make it sound spiteful. He leaves without being dismissed, slamming the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It has been a long day, the Resistance leaders are all exhausted. Beck, Olbricht, Witzleben, Haeften and Mertz watch Goerdeler circling a rigid Stauffenberg.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The point of your central solution is to replace Hitler so that we can negotiate a truce with the Allies. The Allies, I suspect, would be more amenable to a truce... IF WE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Today was a matter of indecision - nothing more. A military operation in the hands of a politician. Stauffenberg's lack of respect infuriates Goerdeler.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think I am alone when I say your judgement is in question. (to the others)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I would like to take a vote.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GOERDELER

dialogues.speaker: STAUFFENBERG.
dialogues.text: BECK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carl, if I may have a word with you in private. GOERDELER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you have something to say, Ludwig, say it here. Say it now. BECK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very well. There's no need to vote. Beck turns to the bar, pours two drinks. Stauffenberg stiffens, ready for the axe. BECK (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I consider you a friend. And I look forward to the day when we can once again live as free men. But you've become a liability. Goerdeler smiles smugly. But the smile fades when Beck turns, offering a drink to him. BECK (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry it has to be this way. GOERDELER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wha... What are you saying? BECK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fellgiebel informed me this evening... Himmler's issued an order for your arrest. You'll have to leave Germany. Tonight. When we've succeeded with the central solution you'll return as Chancellor. Until then- Goerdeler stands, confronting Stauffenberg. GOERDELER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is your doing, isn't it? ISN'T IT? You can't just get rid of me like this. I am the man Germany will follow. I'm... I... Stauffenberg says nothing. He's too cool. Goerdeler looks at the other conspirators, but no one is going to speak for him. Finally, almost in tears:

dialogues.speaker: GOERDELER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Ludwig, I- Beck offers him an envelope. BECK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Disappear, Carl. Avoid contact with anyone. Ugly pause. Goerdeler snatches the envelope and sulks out. We could not be happier to see him go. Beck coughs, turns to Stauffenberg. BECK (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No more indecision. From now on, Stauffenberg has discretion.                        OLBRICHT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't issue Valkyrie again unless we follow through. If he fails to-                  STAUFFENBERG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll do my job. You just take Berlin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON: A telephone. Stauffenberg's three fingered hand picks up the receiver and lifts it out of frame.

dialogues.speaker: STAUFFENBERG, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I'd like to place a call to                         Bamberg, please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nina and her children eat supper around a single candle, Bamberg is experiencing a blackout. Though Nina manages a tranquil facade she is anything but. ANGLE ON: The silent telephone in the foreground. We wait for it to ring, but it never does.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beck enters to find Stauffenberg in the front pew, staring at Christ on the cross.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BECK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you made your peace with God,                 then?                                              STAUFFENBERG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As best I can.                                     BECK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then you have nothing to fear.                     Stauffenberg manages a smile as Beck sits.                STAUFFENBERG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know the soldier inside me is a                  traitor. I wonder how I'll be                      judged as a man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By history?                                        STAUFFENBERG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By God.                                            BECK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the end, we answer only to                      ourselves.                                         Stauffenberg fingers the cross and ring hanging from      the chain around his neck.                                BECK (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you reach your wife?                           STAUFFENBERG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bombing in Ebingen. I can't get                    through.                                           BECK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ebingen is a long way from Bamberg.                They're safe. You've seen to that.                 (realizing...)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To think... You came to us a                       wounded soldier from Africa. Now...                Now you are both the architect and                 the assassin. I'm still trying to                  understand how this came to be.                    STAUFFENBERG                           (more to himself)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like a farmer watching the corn                    grow. One day it's over his head...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing... And the two men look up at the cross in silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In these waking hours Berlin appears quite peaceful. Only the distant sound of shelling reminds us that the city is surrounded by war.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A tawny leather briefcase sits on a neatly made bed. Stauffenberg, freshly bathed and wrapped in a towel, shaves in front of the mirror. For the first time we see his scars and deformities in full. He looks himself over, finally focusing on the chain around his neck, contemplating the small cross and the ring - its engraving: finis-initium [end-beginning]. Though his face is clean-shaven now, he continues, slowly running the razor down his throat. Then he stops, pressing the blade a little too hard and bringing blood. It almost seems intentional. CLOSE ON: The box that holds his glass eye, staring.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stauffenberg has since mastered the process of dressing himself. JUMP CUTS take us from a wounded soldier to an officer of the General Staff. CLOSE ON: His crisp white collar, picking up a trace of blood from the cut on his throat.

dialogues.speaker: TITLES
dialogues.text: Haeften holds the door for Stauffenberg, stepping into a military sedan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For the first time we see Berlin in broad daylight - the city in ruins. The drive through the rubbled, smoky streets is particularly eerie today.

dialogues.speaker: TITLES
dialogues.text: Haeften and Stauffenberg board a three-engine courier plane - each carrying a leather briefcase. A moment later the plane is taking off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A group of 30 RESISTANCE OFFICERS talk quietly, smoking cigarettes and waiting anxiously. Many of the faces we recognize, some we see for the first time. We notice Witzleben has donned his old military uniform, looking a little too proud. Beck looks over the faces of these men, trying to contain his own fear. His eye catches the door opening and a MAN IN A DECORATED POLICE UNIFORM entering the room. We tense. One by one, the men in the room stop talking, staring at the police officer. Just as we think it's over:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gentlemen, may I introduce Chief Helldorf. He's guaranteed the full support of the Berlin Police. Helldorf nods. The men breathe a collective sigh of relief. Some laugh. Many shake Helldorf's hand. BECK (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can begin. Beck moves to a table covered with maps of Berlin, Paris and the Wolf's Lair. BECK (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hitler has scheduled a military briefing for today at one o'clock. Stauffenberg will strike regardless of who else is present.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Beck speaks, we see how things should play out...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stauffenberg and Haeften are driven in a topless sedan. Each carries his leather briefcase.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Once in position, he will signal us once to alert the troops and again after the flash...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stauffenberg and Haeften quickly get in the sedan - the concrete bunker just behind him - its steel door closed. They speed out of frame a beat before a muffled explosion rocks the bunker - the steel door bulges but holds fast. Only a wisp of smoke escapes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SOLDIERS burst into Fromm's office and arrest the bewildered General without incident.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Assuming Fromm refuses to join us, Olbricht will take Command of the Reserve Army and initiate Operation Valkyrie. Olbricht takes Fromm's place and starts making calls. At least this is how it should happen...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Establishing shots of the idle troops and equipment as they are once again called into action.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then he'll notify all district commanders between Paris and Berlin that the SS is attempting to seize power. The Reserve Army will arrest all SS, Gestapo and Nazi officials. The same soldiers are now storming government buildings and seizing personnel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Witzleben and Beck march in with ARMED SOLDIERS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When the time is right, Witzleben and I will arrive at the War Ministry and assume the roles of Commander of the Armed Forces and Head of State, respectively.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goerdeler stands at a radio microphone, reading passionately from a prepared script with dramatic gestures painfully reminiscent of Hitler.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With Berlin secured, Goerdeler will return and address the nation as our new Chancellor. Then, God willing, we can negotiate a truce with the Allies and spare Europe from total destruction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gentlemen, this is the most important day of your lives. Long live sacred Germany. The conspirators salute and leave. Beck places both hands on the table to support himself, coughing and exhausted. Then he looks nervously at his watch...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Olbricht paces before his desk. Mertz watches him, anxiously waiting for:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Put the Reserve Army on standby alert.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not until I hear from Stauffenberg. Not until I'm sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But that's not what he-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Noted, Colonel. Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The plane touches down and taxis to a stop. Stauffenberg and Haeften deplane and immediately step into a waiting courier car driven by a young, dutiful Nazi. SECOND LIEUTENANT KRETZ. Remember him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Even this early, the heat is oppressive. We watch from a distance as the courier car is stopped at the outer checkpoint. Once again, the GUARD carefully examines Stauffenberg and Haeften's identification and takes their pistols before allowing the car to pass. We follow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Est. Field Marshal Wilhelm Keitel's office as the courier car arrives. Stauffenberg and Haeften are greeted by Freyend who shows them to:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TWO OFFICERS are already waiting. They stand...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gentlemen, may I present Colonel Claus von Stauffenberg - Chief Officer of the Reserve Army.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Colonel Stauffenberg. This is an honor. They say you're the man that will defend Berlin from the Red Army single-hand- The officer realizes what a faux pas he has made as soon as he says it. Unfazed, Stauffenberg smiles, raising his briefcase with his single hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: STAUFFENBERG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Indeed. I've got the whole bag of tricks right here. The officers laugh nervously, relieved he was not insulted. Idiots. Meanwhile, Freyend steps toward Haeften, reaching for the handle of his briefcase. FREYEND

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me take that for you. But Haeften snaps the case back. Freyend raises a suspicious eye. Before he can press: VOICE (O.S.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Colonel Stauffenberg? Everyone turns to find General Fellgiebel standing at the door. Everyone stands at attention. FELLGIEBEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At east, Gentlemen.                                   (to Stauffenberg)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: General Fellgiebel, communications.                   I just wanted to meet the hero of                     Africa... And see if there's                          anything you need.                                    STAUFFENBERG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir, there is. I'm expecting a                   call of the utmost importance. Even                   if it comes when I am in conference                   with the FГјhrer I'd appreciate it                     if you had a man come and get me.                     Beat. Fellgiebel and Stauffenberg share an instant look of understanding. FELLGIEBEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course, Colonel. Fellgiebel salutes. Stauffenberg and the others return it as Fellgiebel departs. Just then, Keitel bursts from his office, fixing his tie. KEITEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gentlemen. The meeting has been pushed forward to 12:30. Mussolini is arriving on the afternoon train and Hitler wants to have lunch with him. Stauffenberg is excited by a potential bonus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will Mussolini be in the briefing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I only wish he were. Then some ambitious officer might take the opportunity to shoot the dago bastard. Keitel makes a beeline for the door and the others follow like good sheep. Stauffenberg holds back, however, attracting Freyend's attention.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll need a place to wash up - change my shirt. Stauffenberg points to the shaving cut on his throat and the tiny blood stain on his shirt. The cut was intentional after all. Annoyed, Freyend motions to the adjoining anteroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please, do be quick. You heard the General. Stauffenberg nods in appreciation. He motions for Haeften to follow him. Freyend watches, curious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fast on Stauffenberg's heels, Haeften closes the door. A large portrait of Hitler looms, watching. Stauffenberg positions himself at a small desk with his back to the door. He removes a brick of plastic explosive from his briefcase.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispering)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're arming them... now? Stauffenberg quickly unbuttons his shirt, taking a clean one out of his bag and putting it on as: Haeften assembles a fuse. STAUFFENBERG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No room for error this time. Assume I have ten minutes in this heat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: STAUFFENBERG (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two minutes for the walk, one for the security check and one to the bunker. Three minutes for the walk back. That's seven.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leaving just three minutes to place the bomb.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Plenty of time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If the bomb goes off in ten. He carefully inserts the fuse into the explosive. The RING OF A TELEPHONE startles us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON THE TELEPHONE. Freyend answers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Major Freyend speaking. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stauffenberg? Yes, he's arrived... They are on their way now. Freyend hangs up, glancing impatiently at his watch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neatly dressed again, Stauffenberg carefully places the primed explosive back in his briefcase. He and Haeften turn their attention to the second explosive - assembling the fuse, about to insert it when: BANG. The door swings suddenly open - stopped short by Stauffenberg's backside. He nearly drops the fuse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dammit man, what is it? It's Freyend, of course, trying to peer through the partially opened door. Stauffenberg hides the bombs with his body.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: General Keitel insists that the Colonel please hurry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haeften scoops the unarmed explosive into his briefcase. Stauffenberg motions for Haeften to leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haeften comes out, moving Freyend back with his body and shutting the door behind him - a charged moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Colonel is changing, Major. You understand this can be difficult. Freyend backs down. A little.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stauffenberg produces a pair of pliers (one handle specially bent for easier use by a man with only three fingers). With some effort, he manages to secure the pliers around the fuse. CLOSE ON THE ACID CAPSULE OF THE FUSE. The jaws of the pliers gently squeeze, crushing it. The bomb is live. There is no turning back now. Stauffenberg closes his briefcase and opens the door, greeted by Freyend and Haeften.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Freyend scurries, trying to catch up with Keitel. Stauffenberg and Haeften lag behind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Haeften)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See that the car is ready. Haeften looks down at the briefcase in his hand - the second, unarmed explosive inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But sir-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have everything I need, Lieutenant. Thank you. Haeften reluctantly takes his leave just as Freyend turns back, eager for Stauffenberg to pick up the pace. He reaches for the briefcase.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please. Let me help you with that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pulling it away)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can manage, thank you. Freyend seems more than just a little peeved. But Stauffenberg doesn't notice. He is focused straight ahead, mentally calculating what time he has left. The bunker suddenly seems miles away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Security Perimeter I. Keitel and his men file through the heavily guarded entrance. Each man holds up his pass for the GUARDS to inspect. Stauffenberg is last. Keitel heads toward a wooden structure up ahead - AWAY FROM THE BUNKER. Stauffenberg is confused.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are they going?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's too hot. The briefing has been moved to the conference hut. ANGLE ON: The conference hut. The door and many windows of the flimsy wooden structure are all open. Not ideal for generating the deadly air pressure vital to Stauffenberg's plan. But this obstacle only seems to strengthen his resolve. He is a soldier after all. And no military operation goes according to plan. Making matters worse: FREYEND (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir, your briefcase. I insist. Annoyed but not wanting to arouse suspicion, Stauffenberg finally acquiesces, handing it over. He watches Freyend carry the bomb into the hut. Pause. Stauffenberg looks back over his shoulder to: Fellgiebel - standing by the communications building. The man who will get Stauffenberg out of the room before the bomb goes off. They share a nod. Then Stauffenberg steps into the hut.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the room beyond we see Hitler at the end of a long table surrounded by RANKING OFFICERS. One by one, they present their individual briefings to the nodding FГјhrer. Stauffenberg whispers to Freyend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My injuries left me a bit hard of hearing. See that you place me as near the FГјhrer as possible. Freyend nods, but for now his concerns are elsewhere - wrangling everyone into the meeting. Like the other officers, Stauffenberg hangs up his belt and hat on hooks at the entrance to the briefing room. He catches sight of SERGEANT-MAJOR ADAM, the conference hut's young telephone operator. STAUFFENBERG (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sergeant. I'm expecting an urgent call from Berlin...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A small room measuring 15 by 32 feet. Stifling heat. We notice again that the windows are open to let in some air. Hitler and his officers hunch over a long, heavy table covered in detailed maps of Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union. LIEUTENANTS and SERGEANTS continually tiptoe in and out of the room. A GENERAL stands beside Hitler in the middle of his briefing:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Eastern Front forces are assured a victory... but they need reinforcements. In other words, they are getting pounded but he can't say that. The General is relived to be interrupted by Keitel's arrival. The briefing stops momentary as:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please pardon our tardiness... You remember Colonel Stauffenberg?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hitler makes a deliberate effort to shake Stauffenberg's hand, their eyes lock - an unnerving moment. Stauffenberg has come to kill this man greeting him. The moment is broken when the General clears his throat, continuing his presentation. GENERAL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As you can see, Mein FГјhrer, the situation in the East Prussian sector is increasingly critical... (and on and on...) Freyend startles Stauffenberg slightly when he takes him by the arm, moving him to his place at the table - less than half a step from Hitler. He is squeezed in between two other officers. We suck in wind when we see who one of them is... COLONEL HEINZ BRANDT - the same Brandt who carried the bottles of Cointreau onto Hitler's plane so long ago. He still scribbles in his damn datebook. Freyend sets the briefcase beside Stauffenberg - bumping Brandt's leg. Brandt looks down at the briefcase - long enough to make us nervous. He watches as Stauffenberg nonchalantly bends down, sliding the briefcase as close to Hitler as possible, leaning it against the heavy wooden table support immediately to the right of Hitler's foot. Stauffenberg looks back at the open door, glances at his watch. He can clearly see Sergeant Adam, the telephone operator. Where is his God-damn phone call? Around him generals talk, Hitler nods, but we hear nothing. Only the pulse of Stauffenberg's heartbeat in his own ears - the only thing betraying his otherwise outward calm. He looks down at the briefcase - the bomb just under his feet. He looks at Hitler nodding. The longer we stay, the more excruciating it is. So we milk it. Stauffenberg is startled when a hand touches his arm. The annoying Freyend is there, whispering in his ear. Keitel sees this, irritated by the interruption. Stauffenberg makes a gesture to Keitel with his hand, indicating a phone call. Keitel is not pleased.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Freyend leads Stauffenberg to Adam who offers the telephone receiver.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: General Fellgiebel, sir. He says it's urgent. Stauffenberg takes the phone and stares at Freyend and Adam - they get the idea that this is a private call and leave. When they are gone, Stauffenberg simply lays the receiver down and walks out. Fast. A moment later, Adam returns to the room. He sees the receiver laying there. Odd. Looking down the hallway he sees Stauffenberg quickly exiting the building. Then he notices Stauffenberg's hat and belt still hanging outside the briefing room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Colonel... Colonel, you forgot your-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hitler leans on his elbows carefully studying the map before him as the General's presentation drags on. Brandt moves in closer, filling the void left by Stauffenberg. His foot hits something. He looks at: Stauffenberg's briefcase as it falls over. Slowly, Brandt reaches down, picking up the briefcase, looking around for Stauffenberg. He considers the bag for a moment and we are sure he is going to open it. But then he puts it back under the table. But now the heavy wooden support is BETWEEN Hitler and the bomb.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...And now I believe Colonel Stauffenberg will present us with his deployment for the Replacement Army should the unthinkable occur and the Russians reach- Where is Stauffenberg? Keitel shoots Freyend a look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Freyend steps into the hall. No sign of Stauffenberg. Sergeant Adam approaches, looking confused.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where the hell is Stauffenberg? But Adam shrugs, holding out Stauffenberg's hat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fellgiebel and Haeften watch anxiously as Stauffenberg clears the security checkpoint and walks toward them, slow and deliberate - eerily calm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hitler at the far end of the room, bent over the conference table, leaning on his elbows. A MASSIVE, EAR-SPLITTING EXPLOSION lifts the table up, throwing Hitler back and simultaneously vaporizing the men standing on either side of him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The hut explodes outward like a house of cards. Bodies are thrown clear. Everyone hits the deck except Stauffenberg. He just keeps walking. A great cloud of smoke billows from the ruins. The sky is alive with a swirl of burnt paper scraps and ash. STUNNED OFFICERS are running about. Shouting. Screaming. Absolute chaos. Even knowing it was coming, Haeften is stunned. Stauffenberg walks up to the communications building and takes him by the arm, turning to Fellgiebel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Contact General Olbricht in Berlin. Tell him Hitler is dead. Proceed with Operation Valkyrie. Then sever all communications. Fellgiebel nods and rushes to make the call. Stauffenberg leads Haeften to their waiting car - still driven by young Lt. Kretz.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He too is stunned by the explosion - so much so that he does not think to get out and open the door for his passengers. Stauffenberg climbs in next to Kretz, pushing Haeften in the back. STAUFFENBERG (CONT'D) (to Kretz)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Drive. (Kretz lingers)

dialogues.speaker: LIEUTENANT.
dialogues.text: Kretz snaps out of it and jams the car in gear, speeding off down the forested trail. Stauffenberg and Haeften look back for a clear view of the total destruction. Bodies are carried out of the demolished hut - the grounds littered with the wounded. Surly there is no way the FГјhrer could have survived.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fellgiebel holds a phone to his ear. FELLGIEBEL (INTO PHONE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I said Olbricht. General Olbricht at the War Ministry. The call is urgent. A breathless COMMUNICATIONS OFFICER enters, pointing in mute shock to the ruin outside. COMMUNICATIONS OFFICER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell just happened?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What does it look like? The FГјhrer is- Fellgiebel freezes, something catching his eye. COME AROUND TO HIS P.O.V. Share his horror. Through the window, Fellgiebel has a clear view of the conference hut, or rather what's left. HITLER - limping, dazed, his clothes in tatters - is being led from the smoldering ruins. He is very much:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alive...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kretz brings the car to a sudden stop at the first checkpoint. A barricade is in place. A GUARD approaches. Stauffenberg and Haeften hold up passes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have to get to the airfield at once. Orders form the FГјhrer. The guard signals his men to remove the barricade.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fellgiebel waits to be connected to the War Ministry in Berlin. His Communications Officer awaits orders. This makes it hard for Fellgiebel to speak plainly. He plays up his distress for his audience. FELLGIEBEL (INTO PHONE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am calling from The Wolf's Lair with urgent news for the General. Something terrible has happened... Then he turns his back, lowers his voice. FELLGIEBEL (CONT'D) (whispering)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The FГјhrer is still alive. VOICE (ON PHONE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. Please come again. But Fellgiebel's officer is watching him, trying to hear. Fellgiebel has no choice but to hang up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sever all communications. COMMUNICATIONS OFFICER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Olbricht anxiously hovers over Mertz who shouts into the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MERTZ

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't hear you. Come again. Fellgiebel. FELLGIEBEL. But it's no use. Mertz slowly hangs up the phone. OLBRICHT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, what did he say? MERTZ

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I... couldn't be sure. It sounded as though he said... Hitler is still alive. Olbricht clinches his teeth and starts sweating. OLBRICHT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get him back on the line. MERTZ

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir... The bomb did go off. That much was clear. Fellgiebel's next step will be to sever all communications. Olbricht is confused. Frozen. MERTZ (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Colonel Stauffenberg was explicit. We initiate Valkyrie regardless. OLBRICHT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only Fromm can initiate. You know that. MERTZ

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then lie. Tell him Hitler's dead. Or arrest him. But do it now.                         But Olbricht is frozen. MERTZ (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir... Did you hear me? You have to give the order to initiate Valkyrie. This is our only- OLBRICHT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not doing anything until I talk to Fellgiebel. Get him back on the phone. NOW. Mertz shakes his head bitterly and dials, but he'll never get through.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stauffenberg's car presses on through the woods toward the last security checkpoint, but numerous new road barriers are in place. This is not good. One SERGEANT KOLBE and TWO ARMED SOLDIERS step from the guardhouse, signalling Kretz to stop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No one gets in or out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're on orders from the FГјhrer. We have to get to the airfield immediately. You will step aside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, sir, but my orders are- Stauffenberg steps out of the vehicle and makes a beeline for the guardroom. Kolbe races after him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stauffenberg snatches up the telephone before Kolbe and his men can stop him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get me General Keitel. Stauffenberg wipes a single bead of sweat from his brow. With the guards hovering over him, he turns and casually sits on the desk, blocking the phone with his body. He surreptitiously rests his hand on the telephone cradle, hanging up. He talks to no one. STAUFFENBERG (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes... General Keitel. Stauffenberg here. I can't get past the outer gate. A Sergeant... He looks at Kolbe. Kolbe swallows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kolbe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sergeant Kolbe says no one is getting out... Yes. Yes. Maybe you can explain it to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stauffenberg holds out the phone - staring hard, bluffing harder. Kolbe considers the phone. Finally:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That won't be necessary, Colonel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A humiliated Kolbe watches Stauffenberg's car speed away from the open barriers. Free.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence but for the chattering engine. Kretz is distracted by movement in the rearview mirror. P.O.V. IN REARVIEW MIRROR. Haeften rummages through his briefcase, removing objects Kretz can't make out - tossing them, one by one, into the woods. Haeften realizes he is being watched by Kretz in the mirror and shoots him a look. "Mind your own business." Kretz returns his attention to the road. But something just isn't sitting right with him...

dialogues.speaker: TITLES
dialogues.text: Stauffenberg and Haeften climb aboard a waiting plane. A beat later it is rolling down the runway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Every second we stand here arguing is a second lost.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Olbricht is calm - in full denial. He straightens his tie in the mirror as Mertz paces the room, flustered.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't initiate Valkyrie without confirmation that Hitler's dead. It's too great a risk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about Stauffenberg? What about his risk? He did his part and now you're abandoning him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Watch yourself, Colonel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shouldn't you be consulting Beck?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know just what Beck will say. He's a dying man. What does he have                      to lose? He puts on his hat and coat now, turning to leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At least put the Reserve Army on alert.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't cover up another false alarm. When Stauffenberg returns, when he gives me confirmation. Then                      we'll proceed.                                           Mertz is speechless. As Olbricht walks out:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And where are you going?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The same place you are. Lunch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keitel sits at his desk, listening intently to someone O.S. Although his wounds are superficial, he certainly took a beating in the blast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The one-eyed Colonel...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stauffenberg.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He left the building very abruptly - just before the explosion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Several men left the building before the explosion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. Of course. But...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But what? Spit it out, man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well. The Colonel left his hat. Keitel's expression sours. "Is that all you've got for me?" He is about to say so when that prick Freyend barges in, also banged up. With him is Kretz - Stauffenberg's driver.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pardon the intrusion, sir, but I think you will be most interested to hear what this man has to say.

dialogues.speaker: TITLES
dialogues.text: Forty-five precious minutes have slipped away. Mertz sits alone at Olbricht's desk, lighting a fresh cigarette with the remains of another. The ashtray says he's been at this for quite a while. He stares at the clock, as if attempting to will time forward. His eyes sweep across Olbricht's desk, past his files, his stationery, framed photographs of his family. Then he looks up at a portrait of Hitler. Mertz is struck suddenly with a notion. He looks again at Olbricht's desk. His stationery... "Fuck it." He grabs the stationery and feeds it into a typewriter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mertz approaches a LOWLY TELECOMMUNICATIONS OPERATOR. Awkward pause. A struggle with the soul. Then he hands over a sheet of paper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Orders from General Olbricht. CLACK-CLACK-CLACK-CLACK-CLACK...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Again we are inside the nerve center of Nazi communications. Again the teletypes busily chatter away. And again, Sgt. Helm is curious, watching: STANDBY FOR OPERATION VALKYRIE... The TELETYPE OPERATOR looks up at Helm. "What do I do?" Helm glances over his shoulder to the uptight Lt. Haan - oblivious. Helm shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Send it through. But keep me informed. A SHRILL WHISTLE takes us to...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Once again RESERVISTS and CADETS rush to their homes and scramble to put on their uniforms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The siren, the sculpted eagle and swastika, the pillared stronghold. Tanks and heavy equipment are once again made ready. General Hase issues the alert signal just as he did before, watching the men of the Reserve Army scramble. In the melee we find Lieutenant Hagen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here we go again. He says this to:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Major Remer, the man who was so suspicious last time is even more suspicious now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A light drizzle. A man jabbering in Italian O.S. We get our first good look at the demolished briefing hut. That anyone survived is a miracle. Officers crowd around the smoldering ruins, the FГјhrer himself heading this procession. He wears new clothes, nodding, smiling politely to the jabbering Italian O.S. A slight wince is the only indication that he was damn near blown to bits just hours ago. COME AROUND TO REVEAL none other than BENITO MUSSOLINI speaking an incessant stream of Italian. HITLER'S P.O.V. Blissful silence. Mussolini's blathering falls literally on deaf ears.

dialogues.speaker: TITLES
dialogues.text: Three hours have passed since the explosion. Stauffenberg and Haeften alight from the plane. The airfield is surprisingly calm. No car to meet them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quiet, isn't it? Too quiet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll see where our driver is. Haeften walks over to the office. Stauffenberg looks around the airfield. The silence slowly becomes unnerving. He goes after Haeften.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stauffenberg enters just in time to hear: HAEFTEN (INTO PHONE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean to tell me that the alert is only just going out- Stauffenberg swipes the phone from Haeften.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: STAUFFENBERG (INTO PHONE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is Stauffenberg. Get me General Olbricht.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Olbricht storms in, furious. He stands over Mertz, waving a document in his face - the very same document Mertz typed on Olbricht's stationery.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Explain this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Someone had to do something while you were playing dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We don't know that the FГјhrer is not alive. We don't know any-

dialogues.speaker: SAKE. NOT YOU. BE A MAN.
dialogues.text: Before a fuming Olbricht can respond, the phone rings. Both men look at it - Olbricht is afraid to answer. Mertz shakes his head and picks up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: General Olbricht's office. He looks at Olbricht grimly, holding out the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stauffenberg for you, sir. Olbricht would rather take a live cobra than handle the phone right now. But take it he does.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Note: Intercut between Olbricht and Stauffenberg.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's been three hours, Olbricht.                         What the hell have you been doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've had no confirmation that-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: STAUFFENBERG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dammit man, I saw the explosion                     myself. Nothing else matters now. We are committed. Olbricht sits, color draining from his face. A real "what have I done" moment. OLBRICHT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dear God. STAUFFENBERG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now where is Fromm? Is he with us or did you- OLBRICHT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I- No one has spoken to him yet. Stauffenberg pounds his fist on the wall, furious - for the first and only time showing us a crack in his ultra-cool exterior. He collects himself and looks at his watch. STAUFFENBERG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen to me, Olbricht. Never mind Germany. Never mind Europe. Your life is at stake now, do you understand? If you want to live through the night you'll do exactly as I say. OLBRICHT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I understand. STAUFFENBERG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The second you hang up the phone, initiate Operation Valkyrie in Fromm's name. Then go over to his office in force, give him the choice to join us or place him under immediate arrest. Do I make myself perfectly clear? OLBRICHT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I understand. STAUFFENBERG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am at the airfield now. I will be in Fromm's office in fifteen minutes. Be there when I arrive.                    He slams the phone down, taking us to:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence. With shaking hands, Olbricht moves the portrait of Hitler, exposing a hidden wall safe from which he removes, at last, a thick folder marked:

dialogues.speaker: VALKYRIE
dialogues.text: He looks at Mertz.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get Beck and the others. Tell them                        it's time. Relieved, Mertz nods and rushes out. Olbricht picks up the phone and dials. After a beat, he reads from the first page of the Valkyrie order. OLBRICHT (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is General Olbricht calling on behalf of General Fromm - Commander of the Home Army. Adolf Hitler, is                        dead. A group of radicals from the                        SS are attempting to seize control of the government. Operation Valkyrie is in effect. All military districts, training schools and replacement troops are to take control of essential government offices at once... CLACK-CLACK-CLACK-CLACK-CLACK...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lt. Haans sits at his desk, sensing someone over his shoulder. He turns to find Sgt. Helm, a sheet of paper in his trembling hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The FГјhrer is dead. Skeptical, Haans snatches the paper from Helm. When he looks up, the entire staff is looking at him, some with tears in their eyes - others perhaps hiding a sense of relief. A phone rings. Then another. The chattering teletypes seem to surge into another gear as news of Hitler's death starts to spread.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Long pause. Haans struggles with the sheer size of the moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You all know your jobs. Get to work. Zombie-like, the Operators go back to their teletypes, passing orders along. But one Operator - the one Helm asked to keep him informed - notices something strange about one order in a stack of many he is sifting through.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sergeant. This order is signed by Witzleben.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (taking the paper)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's ridiculous. He`s not even in the army anymore. But sure enough, there is Witzleben's name. Strange. Helm looks over at the devastated Haans, wondering how to handle this. Then, like a good little Nazi:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pass the order along.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RESERVE SOLDIERS are marched into readiness. Vehicles moved into place. As they await further orders...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who told you the FГјhrer was dead?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mertz and a sheepish Olbricht stand before Fromm. A stunned Lt. Herber hovers by the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: General Fellgiebel. At the Wolf's Lair. Fromm is at a loss for words. This just can't be so. He picks up the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FROMM (INTO PHONE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is Fromm. Put me through to The Wolf's Lair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's no use calling, all communication lines are- FROMM (INTO PHONE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. General Fromm for Field Marshal Keitel. Urgent. Mertz and Olbricht are shocked that he got through.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keitel is still nursing a few wounds. FROMM (ON PHONE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's going on up there? The most incredible rumors are circulating in Berlin. Immediately suspicious, Keitel plays dumb, leading...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know what you mean. Everything's in order here. Keitel looks out the window at the still smoldering ruins of the conference hut in the distance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's talk the FГјhrer's been assassinated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another failed attempt. The FГјhrer was never in danger. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By the way, where is your man Colonel Stauffenberg?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stauffenberg? On his way back to Berlin, I should think. At the very mention of his name, Olbricht starts squirming.

dialogues.speaker: KEITEL, (ON PHONE)
dialogues.text: Let me know when he arrives. I'd like a word with him. FROMM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Certainly. Click. After a beat, Fromm hangs up, smug. FROMM (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A false alarm. The FГјhrer is fine. Herber's outward relief stands in sharp contrast to Olbricht's barely contained dread. Then: VOICE (O.S.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a lie. All eyes turn to see Stauffenberg and Haeften appear in the doorway. Mertz lets out a sigh of relief as they push their way past Herber and march into the room. STAUFFENBERG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hitler is dead. Operation Valkyrie is in effect. Fromm stands, pounding his fist on the desk. FROMM

dialogues.speaker: OPERATION VAL- WHO GAVE THE ORDER
dialogues.text: STAUFFENBERG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You did. FROMM

dialogues.speaker: THIS IS NOTHING LESS THAN TREASON.
dialogues.text: STAUFFENBERG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Be that as it may, the Reserve Army is assuming control here in Berlin. We trust you'll join us. FROMM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dammit, man. Do you realize what you've done? The FГјhrer is a- STAUFFENBERG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I delivered the bomb myself. I saw the blast. He is dead. Fromm is stunned on several levels. He slowly sits back in his chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON: Lt. Herber, who sees Stauffenberg as the model Nazi, is more shocked by this than the news of Hitler's death.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This can't be happening. It's some kind of joke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you with us or not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Colonel, if what you say is true you should shoot yourself at once. (to the others)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The rest of you are under arrest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, General. You are. And with those words, Haeften and Mertz draw their pistols, training them on the confused Fromm. Herber is paralyzed - unsure of what to do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know where you think this                        is going, but I suggest you men                          change into civilian clothes and                         find a place to hide.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Haeften)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lock him upstairs in his private quarters. Make sure his phone lines are cut.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stauffenberg, Mertz and Olbricht march with great purpose. They are joined by Beck, coming the other way, wearing a plain dark suit. It is moving to see the old man manage the long walk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not in uniform.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This has to be seen as a movement of the people.                                           Then he takes Stauffenberg's arm, letting Mertz and Olbricht walk on, lowering his voice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're certain he's dead.                                 Certain? Stauffenberg can see the private fear in beck's eyes. But before he can answer, he is interrupted by a gasp O.S. as Olbricht opens the door to his office, stepping back in shock. The others turn to see what it is...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looking out at the shocked faces of Olbricht, Mertz, Beck and Stauffenberg. PULL BACK TO REVEAL: Olbricht's office is packed to the four walls with GERMAN OFFICERS - all of them standing in silence, looking at the leaders of the Resistance with great respect. Stauffenberg walks in and the crowd parts, solemn and silent, nodding and whispering thanks. A YOUNG OFFICER steps forward. He looks hauntingly like the Lieutenant who drove Stauffenberg in Africa.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Colonel Stauffenberg, sir. We're reporting for duty. Stauffenberg is moved beyond words. Suddenly, what was once a small clutch of discarded generals and politicians is now a movement of motivated men. Stauffenberg nods, collects himself. In the crowd he finds Helldorf, the head of the Berlin Police, whom we met earlier. At first he speaks quietly, humbled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shaking hands)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Helldorf, I'm... glad to see you. We're getting a late start and we need all of the manpower we can muster. Can we count on the police?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a lot of talk that Hitler                         isn't really dead. Is this true?                          Awkward pause. Good question. The men in the room share nervous glances. Then all eyes on Stauffenberg.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't offer you any guarantees.                         The decision is yours and yours alone. Can we count on you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Long pause. PAN ACROSS the uneasy faces of the men in the room, perhaps all of them waiting to see what Helldorf does before making their decisions. Finally:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm with you. Stauffenberg can barely hide his relief. There is a palpable shift in the room. One by one, the officers in the room reaffirm their commitment to the coup.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have your men surround the building. No one gets in or out of here without my permission. (to the others)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want every available soldier on task - we need simultaneous control of every government building in the city. Dismissed. The soldiers move, but Beck's voice stops them - surprisingly loud and clear for a sick old man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Acts of vengeance will not be tolerated. We represent a different form of government. We represent what is good and just in Germany.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stauffenberg stands at his cluttered desk, a flurry of activity surrounding him. He is frantically speaking into the phone and to those present.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Deploy troops to seize and protect all Reich agencies. Of most importance are communication centers - newspapers, radio stations, telephone and telegraph offices. All Nazi officials and government leaders are to be arrested at once...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: General Hase, the Berlin Commandant, stands before a giant map of Berlin, addressing a roomful of NAZI OFFICERS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Completely blockade the government quarters. Everything from the Brandenburg Gate to Potsdamer Platz. Nobody, not even generals or ministers, should be allowed to pass. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have your orders, gentlemen. Again, we focus on Major Remer, Commander of the Deutschland Guard Battalion and always suspicious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is there a problem, Major?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It just all seems very... vague, sir. Protocol dictates we should receive orders in writing-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These are the orders as they were presented to me, Major. Now move. Pause. Just before the pause becomes insolent, Remer clicks his heels and salutes, leaving. But the look on his face tells us he's hatching a plan of his own. You are right to be nervous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The city center is abuzz with soldiers and military vehicles as they frantically cordon off the streets. SOLDIERS come out of various government buildings with SEVERAL NAZI GENERALS in custody, hands bound. They push them into waiting trucks. Meanwhile, PASSING CIVILIANS walk quickly by, trying to pretend they don't see anything. Years of Nazi rule have told them to mind their own business.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANGLE ON: A staff car - Major Remer in the back, watching the entire scene with cold eyes. Lt. Hagen emerges from the chaos on the streets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Major Remer. We've just had orders from the War Ministry. The battalion is to blockade the government quarter and place Minister Goebbels under arrest. Remer does not move. He just thinks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it, Major?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Something just doesn't feel right about this. I would hate to find out I'm being taken advantage of.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (realizing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A coup you think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of that I am certain. What I can't say is which side we're on. Get in. As Hagen does, Remer turns to his DRIVER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take us to the Reichministry. Be quick about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stauffenberg, Beck and Olbricht lead a continued effort to manage the coup. Each man shouts orders into the phone, all the while signing dispatches sent by a steady flow of RUNNERS. FRAULEIN VON OVEN (the secretary who worked with Stauffenberg and Tresckow to compile the Valkyrie orders) rushes in, whispering to Stauffenberg.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Send him in. (Oven hesitates)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's all right. Send him in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She opens the door and motions to someone outside. After a beat, the door is filled with an almost classic looking Nazi - A FAT GENERAL bristling with medals. He enters the room, confused when he sees Olbricht at Fromm's desk. FAT GENERAL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Begging your pardon, but I have orders to report to General Fromm. OLBRICHT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: General Fromm is no longer in command. I am. FAT GENERAL

dialogues.speaker: I...
dialogues.text: (seeing Beck)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beck? What are you- What is going on here? STAUFFENBERG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The FГјhrer is dead. The SS is staging a coup. We've initiated Operation Valkyrie to crush the uprising and save Hitler's Germany. The Fat General assesses the scene with suspicion. FAT GENERAL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd say there is a coup all right, but it's not the SS. Olbricht offers a sheet of paper. OLBRICHT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You will present these orders to your troops. FAT GENERAL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will do no such thing without speaking to General Fromm. I swore an oath- STAUFFENBERG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have your orders. Join us or                    face the consequences. Stauffenberg and Olbricht take an imposing step in the Fat General's direction. He carefully backs away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is treason. I won't take part. The FГјhrer is not dead. THE FГњHRER IS NOT DEAD. The Fat General makes a break for it. The conspirators chase him out into...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Fat General pushes past ONLOOKING OFFICERS.

dialogues.speaker: STOP THAT MAN.
dialogues.text: But they just watch the commotion, stunned. A ranking general being chased like a common criminal. Surreal. Haeften and Mertz appear at the other end of the hall - pistols raised, blocking the General's path. With Stauffenberg and Olbricht they overpower the Fat General who screams wildly to the amazement of the gawking officers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE FГњHRER IS NOT DEAD. I'VE SWORN AN OATH. YOU ALL HAVE... When they have him under control, Stauffenberg turns to the onlookers. He finds a familiar face in the crowd. A face he can trust. He finds:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lt. Herber. Come here. ANGLE ON: Lt. Herber. "Who, me?" He reluctantly steps forward. STAUFFENBERG (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lock him up with Fromm. Herber hesitantly takes hold of the General, but the act of taking a General into custody is a strange one. Herber is clearly conflicted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Est. Remer arrives, followed by a wave of trucks. Soldiers deploy, surrounding the building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Propaganda Minister Goebbels - the most ghoulish of Hitler's Big Six. His spooky, deep-set eyes watch the action on the street below. Already he can hear troops coming down the hallway. He takes a pistol from his desk drawer and leaves it within reach. Then he picks up the phone and dials. After a beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am ready to be connected. The sound of footsteps outside his door. It bursts open. Remer enters, followed by ARMED SOLDIERS. GOEBBELS (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What can I do for you, Major?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Minister Goebbels, my battalion has an order to blockade the government quarter and place you under arrest. Remer sees the pistol on Goebbels desk. But Goebbels makes no attempt to grab for it. Instead:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you a dedicated Nazi, Major? Remer is caught off guard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. With that Goebbels turns his attention to the phone in his hand. We hear a faint voice: "Hello?" With an eerie smile, Goebbels simply extends his arm, offering the phone to a confused Remer. Silence as the Major takes it, holding it to his ear...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello? VOICE (ON PHONE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you recognize my voice? Remer is in awe, for a moment unable to speak. Then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course, Mein FГјhrer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HITLER (ON PHONE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then listen to me very carefully...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The communications staff busily connects calls and transmits orders. Sgt. Helm gingerly approaches Lt. Haans with two sheets of paper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it now, Sergeant?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's just that now we're getting conflicting orders, sir. The Wolf's Lair says one thing, Stauffenberg another. Haans sighs, genuinely irritated now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our job is not to interpret the orders. Our job is to pass them along. Regardless.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, but sir-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that perfectly clear, Sergeant? Haans thrusts the orders back at Helm who sheepishly walks back to his pool of radio operators.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As day turns to night, the soldiers surrounding the government quarters wait for further orders. Major Remer comes out a new man - invigorated and focused. He walks over to a truck loaded with RANKING PRISONERS, turning to the soldiers guarding them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (re: prisoners)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Release these men at once.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But these men are part of a coup.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've just been on the phone with Hitler himself. We are the coup, you idiot. We've been duped.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
